and (4) excretion of a larger fraction of filtered $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$restores euvolemia.


## Control of NaCl Excretion During Volume Contraction

During ECFV contraction, the high- and low-pressure vascular volume sensors signal to the kidneys to reduce NaCl and water excretion and thereby restore euvolemia. The signals include:

1. Increased renal sympathetic nerve activity.
2. Increased renin secretion, which increases angiotensin II and aldosterone levels.
3. Inhibition of ANP and BNP secretion by the heart and urodilatin secretion by the kidneys.
4. Stimulation of AVP secretion by the posterior pituitary. The integrated response of the nephron to the signals is described next and illustrated in Fig. 35.13. The numbers below correlate with those in the figure:
5. GFR decreases. Afferent and efferent arteriolar constriction occurs as a result of increased renal sympathetic nerve activity. Because the effect is greater on the afferent arteriole, the hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries falls, which decreases GFR.

Because RPF decreases more than GFR, filtration fraction increases. The decrease in GFR reduces the filtered amount of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$.
2. $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption by the proximal tubule and loop of Henle is increased. Several mechanisms augment $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption in the proximal tubule. For example, increased sympathetic nerve activity and angiotensin II levels directly stimulate $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption. Decreased hydrostatic pressure within the glomerular capillaries also reduces the hydrostatic pressure within the peritubular capillaries. In addition, as just noted, the increased filtration fraction results in an increase in the peritubular oncotic pressure. These alterations in the capillary Starling forces facilitate movement of fluid from the lateral intercellular space into the capillary and thereby stimulate reabsorption of NaCl and water by the proximal tubule (see Chapter 34 for a complete description of this mechanism). Increased sympathetic nerve activity as well as elevated levels of angiotensin II and aldosterone stimulate $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption by the thick ascending limb.
3. $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption by the distal tubule and collecting duct is enhanced. The small amount of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$that is delivered to the aldosterone-sensitive distal nephron, owing to decreased filtration and increased reabsorption by the

proximal tubule and loop of Henle, is almost completely reabsorbed. Stimulation of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption from this segment is enhanced by increased aldosterone levels, although increased sympathetic nerve activity and increased angiotensin II levels may also contribute to this response.
Finally, water reabsorption by the latter portion of the distal tubule and the collecting duct is enhanced by AVP, the levels of which are elevated through activation of the lowand high-pressure vascular volume sensors as well as angiotensin II. As a result, water excretion is reduced. Because both water and $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$are retained by the kidneys in equal proportions, euvolemia is reestablished and body fluid osmolality returns to normal. The time course (hours to days) and
the degree to which euvolemia can be restored depend on the magnitude of ECF contraction as well as the $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$and water intake (enteral or parenteral) and ongoing $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$and water losses (sensible and insensible).

In brief, the nephron's response to ECFV contraction involves the integrated action of all its segments: (1) the filtered amount of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$is decreased; (2) $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption by the proximal tubule and loop of Henle is enhanced (GFR is decreased, whereas proximal reabsorption is increased, and thus glomerulotubular balance does not occur under this condition); (3) delivery of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$to the aldosterone-sensitive distal nephron is reduced in addition to enhanced $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$and water reabsorption from this segment, virtually eliminating urinary $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$and water excretion.

# Key Concepts 

1. Regulation of body fluid osmolality (i.e., steady-state balance) requires that the amount of water added to the body exactly matches the amount lost. Water is lost from the body by sensible and insensible mechanisms. Excretion of water by the kidney is regulated by AVP secreted from the posterior pituitary. When AVP levels are high, urine volume decreases and it becomes hyperosmotic. When AVP levels are low, urine volume increases and its osmolality falls.
2. Disorders of water balance alter body fluid osmolality. Because $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$with its anions is the major determinant of ECF osmolality, disorders of water balance manifest as changes in ECF $\left[\mathrm{Na}^{+}\right]$. Positive water balance (intake > excretion) leads to hyponatremia and decreases body fluid osmolality. Negative water balance (intake
< excretion) leads to hypernatremia and increase body fluid osmolality.
3. The ECFV is determined by the amount of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$in the compartment. To maintain normal ECFV (i.e., euvolemia) $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$excretion must match $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$intake. The kidneys are the major site for regulating excretion of NaCl from the body. Volume sensors located primarily in the vascular system monitor volume and pressure. When ECFV expansion occurs, neural and hormonal signals increase renal excretion of NaCl and water and thereby restore euvolemia. When ECFV contraction occurs, neural and hormonal signals decrease renal $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$and water excretion and euvolemia can be restored. The sympathetic nervous system, RAAS, and natriuretic peptides are important components of the system that maintain steady-state $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$balance.

## $\mathrm{K}^{+}$Homeostasis

Potassium $\left(\mathrm{K}^{+}\right)$is the most abundant cation in the body. The vast majority of total body $\mathrm{K}^{+}$is located intracellularly
(98\%) where the $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$is $150 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$. Only $2 \%$ of total body $\mathrm{K}^{+}$exists in the ECF at a concentration of approximately $4 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$. The large $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$difference across cell membranes ( $\approx 146 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$ ) is maintained by the $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase. The $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$gradient is important in maintaining the potential difference across cell membranes and is critical for the excitability of nerve and muscle cells, as well as for the contractility of cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells (Fig. 36.1). Skeletal muscles contain the largest single pool of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$in the body. In an adult, the skeletal muscles contain approximately 225 times more $\mathrm{K}+$ than all extracellular compartments in the body. Moreover, due to the large number of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase pumps and $\mathrm{K}^{+}$channels, skeletal muscles possess a huge capacity for $\mathrm{K}^{+}$exchange. Despite wide fluctuations of the dietary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$load, $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$remains remarkably constant in the intracellular fluid (ICF) and extracellular fluid (ECF). A $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$in ECF that exceeds $5.0 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$ constitutes hyperkalemia. Conversely, a $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$in ECF of less than $3.5 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$ constitutes hypokalemia. During hypokalemia, skeletal muscle cells release $\mathrm{K}^{+}$to preserve $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$in the ECF leading to total body $\mathrm{K}^{+}$depletion.

## IN THE CLINIC

The $\mathrm{K}^{+}$level is usually determined from a venous blood sample. $\mathrm{K}^{+}$levels were traditionally measured in serum from coagulated blood, but are now more frequently measured in plasma from heparinized blood. Serum levels may generally be 0.2 to $0.4 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$ higher than plasma levels. Inappropriate blood sampling technique may affect the results. $\mathrm{K}^{+}$levels rise in the ECF after physical activity (see later). Thus blood sampling to measure $\mathrm{K}^{+}$should be done after several minutes of rest. Hemolysis of red blood cells during or after phlebotomy will release $\mathrm{K}^{+}$into plasma, thereby artificially elevating $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$in the collected blood sample. Only needles, tubes, and tube adaptors approved for $\mathrm{K}^{+}$measurements should be used to prevent hemolysis. A large vein should be used (e.g., the cubital vein) without fist clenching and without prolonged application of a tourniquet. Pseudohyperkalemia refers to potassium $>5 \mathrm{mmol} / \mathrm{L}$ in the collection tube and normal $\mathrm{K}^{+}$level in patient's blood. In addition to causing pseudohyperkalemia, errors of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$determination may conceal hypokalemia.

Hypokalemia may develop in people with chronic administration of diuretic, excessive use of laxatives, vomiting, eating disorders, or diarrheal illness. Gitelman syndrome (a genetic defect in the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$cotransporter in the apical membrane of distal renal tubule cells) also causes hypokalemia (see Chapter 34). Hyperkalemia may occur in patients with renal failure, or as a side effect of medications such as angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and $\mathrm{K}^{+}$-sparing diuretics in patients with underlying kidney disease (decreased ability to renally excrete $\mathrm{K}^{+}$), or in patients with diabetes mellitus (decreased ability to shift $\mathrm{K}^{+}$intracellularly).

## IN THE CLINIC

Cardiac arrhythmias can result from hyperkalemia and hypokalemia. The electrocardiogram (ECG; Fig. 36.2) (also see Chapter 16) monitors the electrical activity of the heart and is a fast and reliable method to determine whether changes in plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$influence the heart function. The first sign of hyperkalemia is the appearance of tall, thin T waves on the ECG. Further increases in plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$prolong the PR interval, depress the ST segment, and lengthen the QRS interval of the ECG. As plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$approaches $10 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$, the P wave disappears, the QRS interval broadens, the ECG appears as a sine wave, and the ventricles fibrillate (i.e., manifest rapid, uncoordinated contractions of muscle fibers). Hypokalemia prolongs the QT interval, inverts the T wave, and lowers the ST segment of the ECG.

$\mathrm{K}^{+}$absorbed from the gastrointestinal (GI) tract enters the ECF within minutes (Fig. 36.3). If the $\mathrm{K}^{+}$ingested during a normal meal ( $=33 \mathrm{mEq}$ ) were to remain in the

Rapid (seconds to minutes) intracellular uptake of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$is essential to prevent life-threatening hyperkalemia. Excretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$by the kidneys is relatively slow (hours). Maintaining total body $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$constant requires that almost all the $\mathrm{K}^{+}$absorbed from the GI tract is eventually excreted by the kidneys. The colon is responsible for the remaining small fraction of $\mathrm{K}+$ excretion, and in patients with end-stage kidney disease the colon may increase fecal $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion.

## Regulation of Plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$

Several hormones, including epinephrine, insulin, and aldosterone, increase uptake of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$into skeletal muscle, liver, bone, and red blood cells (Box 36.1; see Fig. 36.3) by stimulating $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase and the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{K}^{+} / 2 \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$and $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$cotransporters in these cells. Acute stimulation of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$uptake (i.e., within minutes) is mediated by increased activity of existing $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase and the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{K}^{+} / 2 \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$and $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$cotransporters, whereas a chronic increase in $\mathrm{K}^{+}$ uptake (i.e., within hours to days) is mediated by increased abundance of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase. The rise in plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$that follows $\mathrm{K}^{+}$absorption by the GI tract stimulates secretion of insulin from the pancreas, release of aldosterone from the adrenal cortex, and secretion of epinephrine from the adrenal medulla (see Fig. 36.3). In contrast, a decrease in plasma

$\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$inhibits release of these hormones. Whereas insulin and epinephrine act within a few minutes, aldosterone requires about an hour to stimulate uptake of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$into cells.

## Epinephrine

Catecholamines affect the distribution of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$across cell membranes by activating $\alpha$ - and $\beta_{2}$-adrenergic receptors. Stimulation of $\alpha$-adrenoceptors releases $\mathrm{K}^{+}$from cells, especially in the liver, whereas stimulation of $\beta_{2}$-adrenoceptors promotes $\mathrm{K}^{+}$uptake by cells.

For example, activation of $\beta_{2}$-adrenoceptors after exercise is important in preventing hyperkalemia. The rise in plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$after a $\mathrm{K}^{+}$-rich meal is greater if the patient has been pretreated with a $\beta$-adrenoceptor antagonist (e.g., propranolol). Furthermore, release of epinephrine during stress (e.g., myocardial ischemia) can rapidly lower plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$.

## Insulin

Insulin is the most important hormone that shifts $\mathrm{K}^{+}$into cells after ingestion of dietary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$. Insulin and glucose infusion can be used to correct life-threatening hyperkalemia. In patients with diabetes mellitus (i.e., insulin deficiency), the rise in plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$after a $\mathrm{K}^{+}$-rich meal is greater than in healthy people. In patients with chronic kidney disease, although insulin-stimulated glucose uptake into cells is impaired, insulin stimulation of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$uptake into cells is preserved.

## Aldosterone

Aldosterone, like catecholamines and insulin, also promotes uptake of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$into cells. A rise in aldosterone levels (e.g., primary aldosteronism) causes hypokalemia, whereas a fall in aldosterone levels (e.g., Addison's disease) causes hyperkalemia. As discussed later and as illustrated in Fig. 36.3, aldosterone also stimulates urinary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion. Thus aldosterone alters plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$by acting on uptake of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$into cells and altering urinary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$ excretion.

## Alterations in Plasma [ $\left.\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$

Hyperkalemia usually develops when the amount of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$, either enteral (dietary or bleeding into the GI tract) or parenteral (intravenous administration or hemolysis), exceeds the ability of intracellular uptake and the kidneys to excrete $\mathrm{K}^{+}$(see Box 36.1). Hypokalemia usually develops when intracellular $\mathrm{K}^{+}$uptake and renal $\mathrm{K}^{+}$loss exceeds $\mathrm{K}^{+}$intake (dietary or intravenous) (see Box 36.1). In some situations (see later), changes in the distribution of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$between the ECF and ICF alone can result in acute and clinically relevant disturbances of plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$.

## Acid-Base Balance

Metabolic acidosis increases plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$, whereas metabolic alkalosis decreases it. Respiratory alkalosis causes hypokalemia. In contrast, respiratory acidosis has little or no effect on plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$. Metabolic acidosis produced by addition of inorganic acids (e.g., $\mathrm{HCl}, \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}$ ) increases plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$much more than an equivalent acidosis produced by accumulation of organic acids (e.g., lactic acid, acetic acid, ketoacids). The reduced pH (i.e., increased $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$) promotes movement of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$into cells and the reciprocal movement of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$out of cells to maintain electroneutrality. This effect of acidosis occurs in part because acidosis inhibits the transporters that accumulate $\mathrm{K}^{+}$inside cells, including $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase and the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{K}^{+} / 2 \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$cotransporter. In addition, movement of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$into cells occurs as the cells buffer changes in $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$of the ECF (see Chapter 37). As $\mathrm{H}^{+}$moves across cell membranes, $\mathrm{K}^{+}$moves in the opposite direction, and thus cations are neither gained nor lost across cell membranes. Metabolic alkalosis has the opposite effect; plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$decreases as $\mathrm{K}^{+}$moves into cells and $\mathrm{H}^{+}$exits.

Although organic acids produce a metabolic acidosis, they do not cause significant hyperkalemia. Two explanations have been suggested for the reduced ability of organic acids to cause hyperkalemia. First, the organic anion may enter the cell with $\mathrm{H}^{+}$and thereby eliminate the need for $\mathrm{K}^{+}-\mathrm{H}^{+}$exchange across the membrane. Second, organic anions may stimulate insulin secretion, which moves $\mathrm{K}^{+}$into cells. This movement may counteract the direct effect of the acidosis, which moves $\mathrm{K}^{+}$out of cells.

## Plasma Osmolality

The osmolality of plasma also influences the distribution of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$across cell membranes. An increase in the osmolality of ECF enhances the release of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$by cells and thus increases extracellular $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$. Plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$may increase by 0.4 to $0.8 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$ with a $10 \mathrm{mOsm} / \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$ elevation in plasma osmolality. In patients with diabetes mellitus who do not take insulin, plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$is often elevated, in part because of the lack of insulin and in part because of the increase in plasma [glucose] (i.e., from a normal value of $\approx 100 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{dL}$ to as high as $\approx 1200 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{dL}$ in some cases), which increases plasma osmolality. Hypoosmolality has the opposite action. The alterations in plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$associated with changes in osmolality are related to changes in cell volume. For example, as plasma osmolality increases, water leaves cells because of the osmotic gradient across the plasma membrane (see Chapter 1). Water leaves cells until the intracellular osmolality equals that of ECF. This loss of water shrinks cells and causes $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$ in cells to rise. The rise in intracellular $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$provides a driving force for the exit of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$from cells. This sequence increases plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$. A fall in plasma osmolality has the opposite effect.

## Cell Lysis

Cell lysis causes hyperkalemia as a result of release of intracellular $\mathrm{K}^{+}$into the ECF. Severe trauma (e.g., burns), tumor lysis (i.e., destruction of tumor cells by chemotherapy or natural processes), and rhabdomyolysis (i.e., destruction of skeletal muscle cells) destroy cells and release $\mathrm{K}^{+}$and other cellular contents into the ECF.

## Exercise

During high-intensity exercise or physical exertion, repetitive action potentials in skeletal muscles lead to $\mathrm{K}^{+}$loss from the muscle cells followed by redistribution between plasma and the interstitial fluid (ECF compartment). Because skeletal muscles contain the major pool of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$in the body, plasma $\mathrm{K}^{+}$level may increase up to $8 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$ and the level may be sustained during exercise. Physical conditioning or training reduces exercise-induced hyperkalemia by increasing in the number of $\mathrm{Na}, \mathrm{K}$-ATPase pumps in the skeletal muscle cells. Upon cessation of exercise, recovering muscle cells regain lost $\mathrm{K}^{+}$by the $\mathrm{Na}, \mathrm{K}$-ATPase-mediated $\mathrm{K}^{+}$uptake followed by normalization of plasma $\mathrm{K}^{+}$level within minutes, which may be preceded by a temporary undershoot of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$level and transient hypokalemia. Changes in the $\mathrm{K}^{+}$level during exercise are accompanied by changes in the volume of muscle cells. The contracting muscle cells swell as they lose $\mathrm{K}^{+}$. At cessation of exercise, water moves quickly out of the muscle cells into the interstitial space from where it is slowly redistributed into intravascular space. However, movement of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$ does not seem be important for control of the muscle cell volume.

## $\mathrm{K}^{+}$Excretion by the Kidneys

The kidneys play a major role in maintaining $\mathrm{K}^{+}$balance. As illustrated in Fig. 36.3 the kidneys excrete $90 \%$ to $95 \%$ of the $\mathrm{K}^{+}$ingested from the diet. Excretion equals intake even when intake increases by as much as 10 -fold. This balance in urinary excretion and dietary intake underscores the importance of the kidneys in maintaining $\mathrm{K}^{+}$homeostasis. Although small amounts of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$are lost each day in feces and sweat ( $\approx 5 \%-10 \%$ of the $\mathrm{K}^{+}$ingested in the diet), except during severe diarrhea, this amount is essentially constant, is not regulated, and therefore is relatively less important than the $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excreted by the kidneys. $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion from blood into tubular fluid by cells of the distal tubule (DT) and collecting duct system is the key factor in determining urinary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion (Fig. 36.4).

Because $\mathrm{K}^{+}$is not bound to plasma proteins, it is freely filtered at the glomerulus and is nearly completely reabsorbed in the proximal tubule (through the paracellular pathway in proportion to $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$and water) and ascending limb of Henle (where transcellular $\mathrm{K}^{+}$transport is mediated by the apical membrane $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{K}^{+} / 2 \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$cotransporter). The reabsorptive component of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$is independent of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$intake. Urinary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion results primarily from secretion along the aldosterone-sensitive distal nephron (ASDN), which comprises the last portion of the distal tubule (DT), connecting tubule, and cortical collecting duct (CCD). A rise in dietary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$intake increases $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion (see Fig. 36.4, right panel). In contrast, a low- $\mathrm{K}^{+}$diet activates $\mathrm{K}^{+}$reabsorption along the ASDN (see Fig. 36.4, left panel).

# IN THE CLINIC 

Exercise-induced changes in plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$do not usually produce symptoms and are reversed after several minutes of rest. However, vigorous exercise can lead to life-threatening hyperkalemia in individuals (1) who have endocrine disorders that affect release of insulin, epinephrine (a $\beta$-adrenergic agonist), or aldosterone; (2) whose ability to excrete $\mathrm{K}^{+}$ is impaired (e.g., renal failure); or (3) who take certain medications, such as $\beta_{1}$-adrenergic blockers. For example, during vigorous exercise, plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$may increase by at
least 2 to $4 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$ in individuals who take $\beta_{1}$-adrenergic receptor antagonists for hypertension. The heart may be also exposed to a major drop in $\mathrm{K}^{+}$level at cessation of exercise (see earlier). This drop seems to be associated with impaired cardiac repolarization, which could potentially induce arrhythmia and sudden cardiac death in individuals with pre-existing hypokalemia, ischemic heart disease, heart failure, ventricular arrhythmia, or inherited or acquired long QT-syndrome.

# IN THE CLINIC 

In individuals with end-stage kidney disease, the kidneys are unable to excrete ingested $\mathrm{K}^{+}$and plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$rises. The resulting hyperkalemia reduces the resting membrane potential (i.e., the voltage becomes less negative). The reduced membrane potential decreases the excitability of neurons, cardiac cells, and muscle cells by inactivating fast $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$channels, which are critical for the depolarization phase of the action potential (see Fig. 36.1). Severe rapid increases in plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$can lead to cardiac arrest and death. In contrast, in patients taking diuretics, urinary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion often exceeds dietary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$intake. Accordingly, $\mathrm{K}^{+}$balance is negative
and hypokalemia develops. This decline in extracellular $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$ hyperpolarizes the resting cell membrane (i.e., the voltage becomes more negative) and reduces the excitability of neurons, cardiac cells, and muscle cells. Severe hypokalemia can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, paralysis, and death. Hypokalemia can also impair the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and can stimulate renal production of $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$, which affects acid-base balance (see Chapter 37). Therefore, maintenance of high intracellular $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$, low extracellular $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$, and a high $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$gradient across cell membranes is essential for cellular functions.

Although $\mathrm{K}^{+}$channels are also present in the basolateral membrane, $\mathrm{K}^{+}$preferentially leaves the cell across the apical membrane and enters the tubular fluid. $\mathrm{K}^{+}$transport follows this route for two reasons. First, the electrochemical gradient of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$across the apical membrane favors its downhill movement into tubular fluid. Second, the permeability of the apical membrane to $\mathrm{K}^{+}$is greater than that of the basolateral membrane. Therefore $\mathrm{K}^{+}$preferentially diffuses across the apical membrane into tubular fluid. $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion across the apical membrane via the $\mathrm{K}^{+} / \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$cotransporter is driven by the favorable concentration gradient of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$between the cell and tubular fluid. The three major factors that control the rate of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion by principal cells in DT and CCD include: (1) the activity of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase, (2) the driving forces (electrochemical gradient for $\mathrm{K}^{+}$channels and the chemical concentration gradient for the $\mathrm{K}^{+} / \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$cotransporter) for movement of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$across the apical membrane, and (3) the permeability of apical membrane $\mathrm{K}^{+}$channels to $\mathrm{K}^{+}$. In the DT and CCD $\alpha$-intercalated cells reabsorb $\mathrm{K}^{+}$by a $\mathrm{H}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase (HKA) transport mechanism located in the apical membrane (see Fig. 36.5B). This transporter mediates $\mathrm{K}^{+}$uptake across the apical plasma membrane in exchange for $\mathrm{H}^{+}$. The exit of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$from intercalated cells into the blood is mediated by a $\mathrm{K}^{+}$channel. Reabsorption of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$is activated by a low- $\mathrm{K}^{+}$diet.

## $\mathrm{K}^{+}$Excretion by the DT and CCD

$\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion by the ASDN is determined by plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$, $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$delivery and tubular fluid flow (i.e., $\mathrm{K}^{+}$sensing), aldosterone, arginine vasopressin (AVP), glucocorticoid levels, and acid-base status.

## Plasma [ $\left.\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$

Plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$is an important determinant of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion by the DT and CCD. Hyperkalemia stimulates secretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$ within minutes by several mechanisms. First, hyperkalemia stimulates $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase and thereby increases $\mathrm{K}^{+}$uptake across the basolateral membrane. This uptake raises intracellular $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$and increases the electrochemical driving force for exit of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$across the apical membrane. Second, hyperkalemia also increases the permeability of the apical membrane to $\mathrm{K}^{+}$. Third, hyperkalemia stimulates secretion of aldosterone by the adrenal cortex, which as discussed later, acts synergistically with plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$to stimulate its secretion. Fourth, hyperkalemia also increases the flow rate of tubular fluid, which as discussed later, stimulates secretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$by the DT and CCD.

Hypokalemia decreases $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion via actions opposite to those described for hyperkalemia. Hence hypokalemia inhibits $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase, decreases the electrochemical driving force for efflux of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$across the apical membrane, reduces permeability of the apical membrane to $\mathrm{K}^{+}$, and decreases plasma aldosterone levels.

## 3 AT THE CELLULAR LEVEL

ROMK is the primary channel in the apical membrane of principal cells that mediates constitutive (as opposed flowstimulated) $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion. ROMK has a low conductance and high probability of being open under physiologic conditions. In addition, the $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$-activated BK channel is also expressed in the apical membrane. The BK channel has large single channel conductance and is quiescent in the basal state and mediates $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion under conditions of increased flow discussed earlier. Interestingly, knockout of the KCNJ1 gene encoding ROMK channel causes increased excretion of NaCl and $\mathrm{K}^{+}$by the kidneys, thereby leading to reduced ECFV and hypokalemia. Although this effect is somewhat perplexing, it should be noted that ROMK is also expressed in the apical membrane of the thick ascending limb (TAL) of Henle's loop, where it plays a very important role in recycling of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$across the apical membrane, an effect that is critical for operation of the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{K}^{+} / 2 \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$cotransporter. In the absence of ROMK, reabsorption of NaCl by the TAL is reduced, which leads to loss of NaCl in urine. Reduction of NaCl reabsorption by the TAL also reduces the positive transepithelial luminal voltage, which is the driving force for reabsorption of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$by this nephron segment. Thus the reduction in paracellular $\mathrm{K}^{+}$ reabsorption by the TAL increases urinary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion even when the cortical collecting duct is unable to secrete the normal amount of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$because of a lack of ROMK channels. The CCD, however, does secrete $\mathrm{K}^{+}$even in ROMK knockout mice via the flow and $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$-dependent BK channel expressed in the apical membrane of principal cells.

## III IN THE CLINIC

Chronic hypokalemia $\left(\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]<3.5 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}\right)$ may occur in patients who receive diuretics, abuse laxatives, have profound vomiting or diarrhea, undergo nasogastric suction, or have hyperaldosteronism. Hypokalemia occurs because renal $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion exceeds dietary intake of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$. Vomiting, nasogastric suction, diuretics, and diarrhea can all decrease ECF volume, which in turn stimulates secretion of aldosterone (see Chapter 35). Because aldosterone stimulates excretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$by the kidneys, its action contributes to development of hypokalemia. Hypokalemic nephropathy is a chronic condition in patients with total body $\mathrm{K}^{+}$depletion and is characterized by volume depletion and hyperaldosteronism. It is frequently a progressive form of chronic kidney disease that may lead to end-stage kidney disease.

Chronic hyperkalemia $\left[\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]>5.0 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}\right]$ occurs most frequently in individuals with reduced urine flow, low plasma aldosterone levels, and renal disease in which the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) falls below 20\% of normal. In these individuals, hyperkalemia occurs because renal $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion is lower than dietary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$intake. Less common causes of hyperkalemia occur in people with deficiencies in insulin or aldosterone secretion or in people with metabolic acidosis caused by inorganic acids.

## IN THE CLINIC

Since the agricultural revolution, the human diet evolved from a high $\mathrm{K}^{+}$-low $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$to a low $\mathrm{K}^{+}$-high $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$diet. Recommendations for the adequate $\mathrm{K}^{+}$intake for adults generally range between 90 and $100 \mathrm{mEq} /$ day ( $3500-4000 \mathrm{mg} /$ day). In a worldwide analysis, $\mathrm{K}^{+}$intake (estimated from urinary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion in adults) was $40 \%-50 \%$ lower than the recommended intake. A low- $\mathrm{K}^{+}$diet is associated with increased risk of adverse cardiovascular effects including hypertension and hypokalemic nephropathy. A low- $\mathrm{K}^{+}$diet increases the activity of the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} /$ $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$cotransporter in the DT. This makes sense physiologically, because increased sodium reabsorption by the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} /$ $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$cotransporter reduces $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$delivery to downstream $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secreting nephron segments and therefore helps to conserve $\mathrm{K}^{+}$. The effect of a low- $\mathrm{K}^{+}$diet, which reduces $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$excretion by the kidneys, has been linked to the pathogenesis of salt-sensitive hypertension. Conservation of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$and $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$by the kidneys when there is $\mathrm{K}^{+}$deficiency may have evolved because simultaneous deficiency of dietary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$and $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$was probably faced by early humans. At the present time when the dietary $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$intake is high and $\mathrm{K}^{+}$intake is low, the response of the kidneys to retain $\mathrm{K}^{+}$and $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$may lead to salt-sensitive hypertension.

$\mathrm{Na}^{+}$into cells activates the $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase in the basolateral membrane, thereby increasing uptake of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$across the basolateral membrane and consequently elevating cell $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$. It is important to note that an increase in flow rate during a water diuresis does not have a significant effect on excretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$, most likely because during a water diuresis the $\left[\mathrm{Na}^{+}\right]$ of tubule fluid does not increase as flow rises.

## Aldosterone

Chronically elevated ( $\geq 24$ hours) plasma aldosterone levels enhance $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion across principal cells in the ASDN (Fig. 36.7): (1) by increasing the amount of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase in the basolateral membrane; (2) by increasing expression of the epithelial sodium channel ( ENaC ) in the apical cell membrane; (3) by elevating SGK1 (serum glucocorticoidstimulated kinase) levels, which also increases expression of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}(\mathrm{ENaC})$ channels in the apical membrane and activates $\mathrm{K}^{+}$channels; (4) by stimulating CAP1 (channelactivating $\boldsymbol{\sim}$ protease, also called prostatin), which directly activates ENaC ; and (5) by stimulating the permeability of the apical membrane to $\mathrm{K}^{+}$. Aldosterone increases the permeability of the apical membrane to $\mathrm{K}^{+}$by increasing the number of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$channels in the membrane. However, the cellular mechanisms involved in this response are not completely known. Increased expression of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase facilitates uptake of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$across the basolateral membrane into cells and thereby elevates intracellular $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$. The increased number and activity of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$channels enhance entry of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$into the cell from tubular fluid, an effect that depolarizes the apical membrane voltage. Depolarization of the apical membrane and increased intracellular $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$ enhance the electrochemical driving force for secretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$from the cell into the tubule fluid. Taken together, these actions increase uptake of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$into the cell across the

Although an acute (within hours) increase in aldosterone levels enhances the activity of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase, $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion does not increase immediately. The delay results from the effect of aldosterone on $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption and tubular flow. Aldosterone stimulated $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$and water reabsorption decreases tubular flow that, in turn, decreases $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion (as discussed in more detail later). However, chronic stimulation of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption increases the ECF volume and thereby returns tubular flow to normal. These actions allow a direct stimulatory effect of aldosterone on the ASDN to enhance $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion.

## AVP

Although AVP does not affect urinary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion, this hormone promotes secretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$by the ASDN (Fig. 36.8). AVP increases the electrochemical driving force for exit of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$ across the apical membrane of principal cells by stimulating uptake of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$across the apical membrane of these cells. The increased $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$uptake reduces the electrical potential difference across the apical membrane (i.e., the interior of the cell becomes less negative). Despite this effect, AVP does not change $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion by these nephron segments. The reason for this relates to the effect of AVP on tubular fluid flow. AVP decreases flow of tubular fluid by stimulating water reabsorption. The decrease in tubular flow in turn reduces secretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$(explained later). The inhibitory effect of decreased flow of tubular fluid offsets the stimulatory effect of AVP on the electrochemical driving force for exit of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$ across the apical membrane (see Fig. 36.8). If AVP did not
increase the electrochemical gradient favoring $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion, urinary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion would fall as AVP levels increased and urinary flow rates decreased. Hence $\mathrm{K}^{+}$balance would change in response to alterations in water balance. Thus the effects of AVP on the electrochemical driving force for exit of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$across the apical membrane and on tubule flow enable urinary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion to be maintained constant despite wide fluctuations in water excretion.

## Glucocorticoids

Glucocorticoids increase urinary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion. This effect is mediated in part by increasing GFR, which enhances the urinary flow rate, a potent stimulus of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion, and by stimulation of SGK1 activity (see earlier).

As discussed, the rate of urinary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion is frequently determined by simultaneous changes in hormone levels, acid-base balance, or the flow rate of tubule fluid (Table 36.1). The powerful effect of flow often enhances or opposes the response of the ASDN to hormones and changes in acid-base balance. This interaction can be beneficial in the case of hyperkalemia, in which the increase in flow enhances excretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$and thereby restores $\mathrm{K}^{+}$homeostasis. However, this interaction can also be detrimental, as in the case of metabolic alkalosis, in which changes in flow and acid-base status alter $\mathrm{K}^{+}$homeostasis.

## The Acid-Base Status

Both acute (within minutes to hours) and chronic (within days) acid-base disturbances have complex effects on $\mathrm{K}^{+}$ handling by the ASDN and renal $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion. The effects of metabolic acidosis on renal $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion are time dependent. As illustrated in Fig. 36.9, an acute acidemia (i.e., plasma pH below normal) reduces $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion via two mechanisms: (1) inhibition of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase that reduces

Acute alkalemia (i.e., plasma pH above normal) has the opposite effects and increases $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion.

Chronic acidemia promotes renal $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion leading to negative $\mathrm{K}^{+}$balance (see Fig. 36.9). This occurs because chronic metabolic acidosis decreases reabsorption of water and solutes (e.g., NaCl ) by inhibiting $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase in the proximal tubule. Hence the flow of tubular fluid is augmented along the ASDN. Inhibition of water and NaCl reabsorption by the proximal tubule also decreases ECF volume and thereby stimulates secretion of aldosterone. In addition, chronic acidosis caused by inorganic acids increases plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$, which stimulates secretion of aldosterone. The rise in tubular fluid flow, plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$, and aldosterone levels offsets the effects of acidosis on cell $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$and apical membrane permeability, and $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion rises. Thus metabolic acidosis may either inhibit or stimulate excretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$, depending on the duration of the disturbance. As noted, acute metabolic alkalosis stimulates excretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$. Chronic metabolic alkalosis, especially in association with ECF contraction, significantly increases renal $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion because of the associated increase in aldosterone levels.

The directional effects of acidemia and alkalemia on $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion are similar in respiratory acid-base disturbances as in metabolic disturbances, but the effects of respiratory disorders on $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion tend to be smaller than metabolic acid-base disturbances. ## 3 AT THE CELLULAR LEVEL

The cellular mechanisms whereby the dietary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$content and acid-base status regulate secretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$by the early segment of the ASDN have recently been elucidated. Elevated $\mathrm{K}^{+}$intake increases secretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$by several mechanisms. Hyperkalemia increases the activity of the ROMK channel in the apical plasma membrane of principal cells. Moreover, hyperkalemia inhibits reabsorption of NaCl and water by the proximal tubule, thereby increasing the ASDN flow rate, a potent stimulus to secretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$(Fig. 36.6). Hyperkalemia also increases aldosterone levels, which increases $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion by three mechanisms. First, aldosterone increases the number of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$channels in the apical plasma membrane. Second, aldosterone stimulates uptake of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$across the basolateral membrane by increasing the number of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase pumps, thereby enhancing the electrochemical gradient driving secretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$across the apical membrane. Third, aldosterone increases movement of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$across the apical membrane, which depolarizes the apical plasma membrane voltage and thus increases the electrochemical gradient, promoting secretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$. A low- $\mathrm{K}^{+}$diet dramatically reduces secretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$by the ASDN by increasing the activity of a tyrosine kinase, which causes ROMK channels to be endocytosed from the apical plasma membrane, thereby reducing $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion. Metabolic acidosis with acidemia decreases secretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$by inhibiting the activity of ROMK channels, whereas metabolic alkalosis with alkalemia stimulates secretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$ by enhancing ROMK channel activity.
by hyperventilation, is associated with $\alpha$-adrenergic stimulation that increases plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$by inhibiting intracellular $\mathrm{K}^{+}$uptake. Acute respiratory alkalosis is a frequent acid-base disturbance in clinical settings including chest pain, anxiety, drugs, hypoxemia, and infection. Chronic respiratory alkalosis usually increases renal $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion and lowers plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$.

## Overview of Calcium and Inorganic Phosphate Homeostasis

$\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and inorganic phosphate $\left(\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right)^{+}$are multivalent ions that subserve many complex and vital functions. $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$is a cofactor in enzymatic reactions and a second messenger in many signaling pathways critical for the homeostasis. $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ is essential for metabolic processes, including formation of adenosine triphosphate (ATP), and it is an important component of nucleotides, nucleosides, and phospholipids. Phosphorylation of proteins is an important mechanism of cellular signaling, and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ is an essential buffer in cells, plasma, and urine. $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ are critical elements of the extracellular matrix, cartilage, teeth, and bone.

The kidneys regulate total body $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ by excreting the amount of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ that is absorbed by the GI tract (normal bone remodeling results in no net addition of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$ and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ to, or $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ release from, bone). If plasma concentrations of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ decline substantially, intestinal absorption, bone resorption (i.e., loss of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ from bone), and renal tubular reabsorption increase and return plasma concentrations of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ to normal levels. During growth and pregnancy, intestinal absorption exceeds urinary excretion, and these ions accumulate in newly formed fetal tissue and bone. In contrast, bone disease (e.g., osteoporosis) or a decline in lean body mass increases urinary $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ loss without a change in intestinal absorption. These conditions produce a net loss of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ from the body. Finally, during chronic renal failure, $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ accumulates in the body because the intestinal absorption of $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ exceeds the urinary excretion leading to accumulation of $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ in the body and bone remodeling (see the In The Clinic box discussion of end-stage kidney disease).

This brief introduction reveals that kidneys, in conjunction with the GI tract and bone, play a major role in maintaining plasma $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ levels as well as $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ homeostasis (see Chapter 40). Accordingly, this section of the chapter discusses $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ handling by the kidneys, with an emphasis on the hormones and factors that regulate urinary excretion.

## Calcium

Cellular processes in which $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$plays an important role include bone formation, cell division and growth, hemostasis, hormone-response coupling, and electrical stimulus-response coupling (e.g., muscle contraction,

The total $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$in plasma is $10 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{dL}$ ( 2.5 mM or $5 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$ ), and its concentration is normally maintained within very narrow limits. Approximately 50\% of the $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$in plasma is ionized (i.e., free), $40 \%$ is bound to plasma proteins (mainly albumin), and $10 \%$ is complexed to several anions, including $\mathrm{PO}_{4}{ }^{3-}, \mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$, citrate, and $\mathrm{SO}_{4}{ }^{2-}$ (Fig. 36.10). The pH of plasma influences this distribution (Fig. 36.11). The total measured plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$ does not reflect the physiologically relevant ionized $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$. Acidemia increases the ionized $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$at the expense of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$ bound to proteins, whereas alkalemia decreases the ionized $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$by increasing the $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$bound to proteins. Individuals with alkalemia are susceptible to tetany (tonic muscular spasms), whereas individuals with acidemia are less susceptible to tetany, even when total plasma $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$levels are reduced. The increase in $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$in patients with metabolic acidosis causes more $\mathrm{H}^{+}$to bind to plasma proteins, $\mathrm{PO}_{4}{ }^{3-}$, $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$, citrate, and $\mathrm{SO}_{4}{ }^{2-}$, thereby displacing $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$. This displacement increases the plasma ionized $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$. In alkalemia the $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$of plasma decreases. Some $\mathrm{H}^{+}$ions dissociate
from plasma proteins, $\mathrm{PO}_{4}{ }^{3-}, \mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$, citrate, and $\mathrm{SO}_{4}{ }^{2-}$ in exchange for $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$, thereby decreasing the ionized $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$. The plasma albumin concentration also affects $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$. Hypoalbuminemia decreases the total $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$and may not accurately reflect the ionized $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$, whereas hyperalbuminemia has the opposite effect on total $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$. It is widely accepted in clinical practice to assume that the total $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$ falls by $0.8 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{dL}(0.2 \mathrm{mmol} / \mathrm{L})$ for every $1 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{dL}(10 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{L})$ fall in the serum albumin concentration.

A low ionized $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$increases the excitability of nerve and muscle cells and can lead to hypocalcemic tetany. Tetany associated with hypocalcemia occurs because hypocalcemia causes the threshold potential to shift to more negative values (i.e., closer to the resting membrane voltage) (Fig. 36.12). An elevated ionized $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$may decrease neuromuscular excitability or produce cardiac arrhythmias, lethargy, disorientation, and even death. This effect of hypercalcemia occurs because an elevated ionized $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$ causes the threshold potential to shift to less negative values (i.e., farther from the resting membrane voltage). The $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$is regulated within a very narrow range, primarily by parathyroid hormone (PTH) and the active metabolite of vitamin D calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin $\mathrm{D}_{3}$ ).

Intracellular $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$is sequestered in the endoplasmic reticulum and mitochondria, or it is bound to proteins. Thus the intracellular ionized $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$is very low ( $\approx 100 \mathrm{nM}$ ). The large concentration gradient for $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$across cell membranes is maintained by a $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$-ATPase pump (PMCalb) in all cells and by a $3 \mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{Ca}^{++}$exchanger (NCX1) in some cells.

## Overview of Calcium Homeostasis

$\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$homeostasis depends on: (1) the $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$absorption from the GI tract, (2) the distribution of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$between the bone and ECF, and (3) the regulation of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion by the kidneys. The total body $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$content is determined by the amounts of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$absorbed from the GI tract and excreted by the kidneys (Fig. 36.13). The GI tract absorbs $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$ through an active carrier-mediated transport mechanism that is stimulated by calcitriol produced in the proximal tubule of the kidneys. Net $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$absorption from the GI tract is approximately $200 \mathrm{mg} /$ day, but it can increase to $600 \mathrm{mg} /$ day when calcitriol levels rise. Daily $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion by the kidneys equals the amount absorbed by the GI tract ( $200 \mathrm{mg} /$ day), and it changes in parallel with intestinal absorption. Thus $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$balance is maintained because the amount of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$ingested in an average diet ( $1000 \mathrm{mg} /$ day) equals the amount lost in feces ( $800 \mathrm{mg} /$ day) plus the amount excreted in urine ( $200 \mathrm{mg} /$ day).

The control of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$distribution between the bone and ECF is mediated by PTH and calcitriol (see Fig. 36.13). PTH is secreted by the parathyroid glands in response to decreased plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$(i.e., hypocalcemia). PTH increases plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$by: (1) stimulating bone resorption, (2) increasing $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$reabsorption by the DT of the kidneys, and (3) stimulating the production of calcitriol, which in turn increases $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$absorption by the GI tract. Production of calcitriol in the kidneys is stimulated by hypocalcemia and

It also enhances renal $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$reabsorption by increasing expression of the $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$binding and transporting proteins in the kidneys (details discussed later). Plasma $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$is an agonist of the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR), expressed on the surface of cells involved in $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$homeostasis: PTH-secreting parathyroid cells, calcitonin-secreting thyroid cells, cal-citriol-producing proximal tubular cells, and TAL cells (discusser later). CaSR, activated by increased ionized $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$, inhibits PTH release by the parathyroid gland and calcitriol production by the proximal tubule. The net effects of CaSR
activation are decreased renal $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$reabsorption, decreased plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$and blunted PTH-mediated phosphaturic effect (less renal $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion). CaSR plays a major role in the steady-state plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$by responding immediately to small changes plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$. Calcitonin is secreted by thyroid C cells (parafollicular cells), and its secretion is stimulated by hypercalcemia. Calcitonin decreases plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$, mainly by stimulating bone formation (i.e., deposition of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$in bone). Although it plays an important role in $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$homeostasis in lower vertebrates, calcitonin plays only a minor role in $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$homeostasis in humans, so it will not be discussed further.

## IN THE CLINIC

Conditions that lower PTH levels (i.e., hypoparathyroidism after parathyroidectomy for an adenoma) reduce plasma [ $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$], which can cause hypocalcemic tetany (intermittent muscular contractions). In severe cases, hypocalcemic tetany can cause death by asphyxiation. Hypercalcemia can cause lethal cardiac arrhythmias and decreased neuromuscular excitability. Clinically hypercalcemia is most commonly caused by primary hyperparathyroidism and malignancy. Primary hyperparathyroidism results from overproduction of PTH by a benign tumor of the parathyroid glands. In contrast, malignant tumors such as carcinomas secrete a PTH-like hormone maned parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP). Increased levels of PTH and PTHrP lead to hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria (increased urinary calcium excretion).

## Calcium Transport Along the Nephron

The $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$available for glomerular filtration consists of the ionized fraction and the $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$complexed with anions. Thus about $60 \%$ of the $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$in plasma is available for glomerular filtration. Normally $99 \%$ of filtered $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$is reabsorbed by the nephron (Fig. 36.14). The proximal tubule reabsorbs about $50 \%$ to $60 \%$ of the filtered $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$. Another $15 \%$ is reabsorbed in the loop of Henle (mainly the cortical portion of the TAL), about $10 \%$ to $15 \%$ is reabsorbed by the DT, and less than $1 \%$ is reabsorbed by the collecting duct. About $1 \%(200 \mathrm{mg} /$ day $)$ is excreted in urine. This fraction is equal to the net amount absorbed daily by the GI tract.
$\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$reabsorption by the proximal tubule occurs primarily via the paracellular pathway. This passive paracellular reabsorption of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$is driven by the lumen-positive

transepithelial voltage across the second half of the proximal tubule and by a favorable concentration gradient of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$, both of which are established by transcellular $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$and water reabsorption in the first half of the proximal tubule (see Chapter 34).
$\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$reabsorption by the loop of Henle also occurs primarily via the paracellular pathway. Like the proximal tubule, $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption in the TAL parallel each other. These processes are parallel because $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$is reabsorbed passively via the paracellular route secondary to $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption that generates a lumen-positive voltage. Loop diuretics inhibit $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption by the TAL of the loop of Henle, and in so doing reduce the magnitude of the lumenpositive voltage (see Chapter 34). This action in turn inhibits reabsorption of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$via the paracellular pathway. Thus loop diuretics can be used to increase renal $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion in patients with hypercalcemia.


## AT THE CELLULAR LEVEL

Mutations in the tight junction protein claudin-16 (CLDN16) reduce the permeability of the paracellular pathway to $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$ and $\mathrm{Mg}^{++}$and thereby reduce the diffusive reabsorptive movement of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{Mg}^{++}$across tight junctions in the TAL of Henle's loop. Familial hypomagnesemic hypercalciuria is caused by mutations in claudin-16, which is a component of the tight junctions in TAL cells. This disorder is characterized by enhanced excretion of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{Mg}^{++}$due to a fall in passive reabsorption of these ions across the paracellular pathway in the TAL. Affected individuals have high levels of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$in their urine, which may lead to kidney stone formation (nephrolithiasis).

In the DT where the voltage in the tubule lumen is electrically negative with respect to blood, reabsorption of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$ is entirely active because $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$is reabsorbed against its electrochemical gradient (Fig. 36.15). Thus $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$reabsorption by the DT is exclusively transcellular. $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$enters the cell across the apical membrane through $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$permeable ion channels (TRPV5). Inside the cell, $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$binds to calbindinD28K. The calbindin- $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$complex carries $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$across the cell and delivers $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$to the basolateral membrane, where it is extruded from the cell primarily by the $3 \mathrm{Na}^{+} / 1 \mathrm{Ca}^{++}$antiporter (NCX1); however, plasma membrane $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$-ATPase isoform 1b (PMCA1b) may also contribute. Urinary $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$ and $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion usually change in parallel. However, excretion of these ions does not always change in parallel, because reabsorption of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$by the DT is independent and differentially regulated. For example, thiazide diuretics inhibit $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption by the DT and stimulate $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$reabsorption by this segment. Accordingly, the net effects of thiazide diuretics are to increase urinary $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$excretion and reduce urinary $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion. Because thiazide diuretics reduce urinary $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion, they are often used to reduce urinary $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion in individuals who produce $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$-containing kidney stones.

## Regulation of Urinary Calcium Excretion

Several hormones and factors influence urinary $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion. PTH exerts the most powerful control (Table 36.2). PTH stimulates $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$reabsorption by the kidneys (i.e., inhibits renal $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion). Although PTH inhibits reabsorption of $\mathrm{Na}+$ and water, and therefore $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$reabsorption by the proximal tubule, it stimulates $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$reabsorption by the TAL of the loop of Henle and the DT. Thus the net effect of PTH is to enhance renal $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$ reabsorption.

Changes in plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$also regulate urinary $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$ excretion, with hypercalcemia increasing excretion and hypocalcemia decreasing excretion. Hypercalcemia increases urinary $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion by: (1) reducing proximal tubule $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$reabsorption (reduced paracellular reabsorption due to increased interstitial fluid $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$); (2) inhibiting $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$reabsorption by the TAL of the loop of Henle via activation of the CaSR located in the basolateral membrane of these cells ( $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption is decreased, thereby reducing the magnitude of the lumenpositive); and (3) suppressing $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$reabsorption by the DT by reducing PTH levels. As a result, urinary $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$ excretion increases. Hypocalcemia has the opposite effect on urinary $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion, primarily by increasing $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$ reabsorption by the proximal tubule and TAL. Calcitriol
enhances $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$reabsorption by the DT, but it is less effective than PTH.

Several factors affect renal $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion. Increased plasma $\left[\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right]$ (e.g., caused by increased dietary $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ load or reduced kidney function) inhibits renal $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion by reducing plasma ionized $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$with subsequent stimulation of PTH secretion. A decline in plasma $\left[\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right]$ (e.g., caused by dietary $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ depletion) has the opposite effect (Note: with normal kidney function, changes in dietary $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ intake over a sevenfold range have no effect on plasma $\left[\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right]$ ). The CaSR expressed in the TAL directly increases renal $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion in response to elevated plasma ionized $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$(discussed earlier). By contrast, a fall in plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$leads to an increase in $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$absorption by the TAL and a corresponding decrease in urinary $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion. The direct effect of plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$on CaSR in the TAL acts in parallel with PTH, which regulates $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$absorption by the DT and controls urinary $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion to maintain its homeostasis. Changes in ECF volume alter $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion mainly by affecting $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$and water reabsorption in the proximal tubule. ECF contraction increases $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$and water reabsorption by the proximal tubule and thereby enhances $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$ reabsorption. Accordingly, urinary $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion declines. ECF expansion has the opposite effect. Acidemia increases $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion, whereas alkalemia decreases excretion. ## IN THE CLINIC

Mutations in the gene coding for CaSR cause disorders in the $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$homeostasis. Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH) is a haploinsufficient state caused by an inactivating mutation in the CaSR gene. The hypercalcemia is caused by altered $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$-regulated PTH secretion (i.e., the set point for $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$-regulated PTH secretion is shifted) such that PTH levels are elevated at any level of plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$and are not suppressed by hypercalcemia. Enhanced $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$reabsorption in the TAL and DT owing to elevated PTH levels and defective CaSR regulation of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$transport in the kidneys lead to hypocalciuria. Autosomal dominant hypoparathyroidism is caused by an activating mutation in the CaSR gene. Activation of CaSR changes the set point for $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$-regulated PTH secretion such that PTH levels are decreased at any level of plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$. Decreased PTH levels and defective CaSRregulated $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$transport in the kidneys lead to hypercalciuria. CaSR activates the thiazide-sensitive $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$cotransporter in the early segment of the DT via the WNK (with no $\mathrm{K}=$ lysine) kinase signaling pathway (see Chapter 34). Activation of the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$cotransporter reduces $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$reabsorption leading to hypercalciuria. Inactivation of the cotransporter increases $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$ reabsorption and hypercalciuria resolves. Thus activation of CaSR increases activity of the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$cotransporter leading to increased NaCl reabsorption, exacerbation of renal $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$ excretion, and hypercalcuria.

## Phosphate

$P_{i}$ is an important component of many essential cellular components, including DNA, RNA, ATP, nucleotides, nucleosides, phospholipids and intermediates of metabolic pathways. Like $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$it is a major constituent of bone. Its concentration in plasma is an important determinant of bone formation and resorption. In addition, urinary $P_{i}$ is an important buffer (i.e., it is one of many titratable acids) involved in the maintenance of acidbase balance (see Chapter 37). Approximately $85 \%$ of $P_{i}$ is located in bone and teeth, $14 \%$ is located in the ICF, and $1 \%$ in the ECF. Normal plasma $\left[P_{i}\right]$ is 3 to $4 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{dL}(1-1.5 \mathrm{mM})$. Plasma $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ is ionized ( $45 \%$ ), complexed (30\%), or bound to protein (25\%). $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ deficiency causes muscle weakness, rhabdomyolysis, and reduced bone mineralization resulting in rickets (in children) and osteomalacia (in adults).

## Overview of Phosphate Homeostasis

$P_{i}$ homeostasis depends on: (1) the $P_{i}$ absorption from the GI tract, (2) the distribution of $P_{i}$ between bone and ECF, and (3) the regulation of $P_{i}$ excretion by the kidneys (see Fig. 36.16).

The total body $P_{i}$ level is determined by the amounts of $P_{i}$ absorbed from the GI tract and excreted by the kidneys. $P_{i}$ absorption from the GI tract occurs via active and passive mechanisms; $P_{i}$ absorption increases as dietary $P_{i}$ rises, and it is stimulated by calcitriol. Despite variations in $P_{i}$ intake between 800 and $1500 \mathrm{mg} /$ day, in adults at the steady state the kidneys maintain total body $P_{i}$ balance constant by excreting an amount of $P_{i}$ in

![be58794790948](be58794790948.jpg)

- Fig. 36.16 Overview of $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ homeostasis. PTH, parathyroid hormone. (From Koeppen BM, Stanton BA. Renal Physiology. 5th ed. Philadelphia: Elsevier; 2013.)
the urine equal to the amount absorbed by the GI tract (normal bone remodeling results in no net $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ addition or release from bone). By contrast, during growth, $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ is accumulated in the body. Renal $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion is the primary mechanism by which the body regulates $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ balance and homeostasis.

Plasma $\left[\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right]$ is controlled by PTH, calcitriol, and FGF-23. PTH releases $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ from bone (see Fig. 36.16). Renal $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion is increased by PTH and inhibited by calcitriol.

Maintenance of plasma $\left[\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right]$ is essential for optimal $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$$\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ complex formation required for bone mineralization without deposition of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++} \mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ in vascular and other soft tissues. A rise in plasma $\left[\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right]$ directly stimulates PTH synthesis and release and decreases the ionized $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$, which stimulates PTH release by its interaction with CaSR. PTH enhances urinary $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion by inhibiting $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ reabsorption in the proximal tubule. Hyperphosphatemia also decreases calcitriol production by the proximal tubule, which leads to a reduction in $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ absorption from the GI tract. Both the increase in PTH and the decrease in calcitriol reduce plasma $\left[\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right]$.

## Phosphate Transport Along the Nephron

Fig. 36.17 summarizes $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ transport by the various portions of the nephron. The proximal tubule reabsorbs $80 \%$ of the $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ filtered by the glomerulus; the loop of Henle, DT, and CCD reabsorb negligible amounts of $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$. Therefore approximately $20 \%$ of the $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ filtered across the glomerular capillaries is excreted in urine.
$\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ reabsorption by the proximal tubule occurs by a transcellular route (Fig. 36.18). $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ uptake across the apical membrane of the proximal tubule occurs via two $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ cotransporters (IIa and IIc). $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ IIa transports $3 \mathrm{Na}^{+}$with

# IN THE CLINIC 

In patients with end-stage kidney disease, the kidneys cannot excrete $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$. Because of continued $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ absorption by the Gl tract, $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ accumulates in the body and plasma $\left[\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right]$ rises. The excess $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ complexes with $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and reduces the ionized plasma [Ca ${ }^{+}$]. $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ accumulation also decreases production of calcitriol. This response reduces $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$absorption by the Gl tract, an effect that further reduces plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$. This reduction in plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$increases PTH secretion and $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$release from bone. These actions result in renal osteodystrophy (i.e., increased bone resorption with replacement by fibrous tissue, which renders bone more susceptible to fracture).

Chronic hyperparathyroidism (i.e., elevated PTH levels due the elevated plasma $P_{i}$ ) during end-stage kidney disease can lead to metastatic calcifications in which $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ precipitate in arteries, soft tissues, and viscera. Deposition of $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $P_{i}$ in the heart may cause myocardial failure. Prevention and treatment of hyperparathyroidism and $P_{i}$ retention include a low- $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ diet and administration of a "phosphate binder" (i.e., an agent that forms insoluble $P_{i}$ salts and thereby renders $P_{i}$ unavailable for absorption from the Gl tract) in the diet. Supplemental calcitriol is also prescribed to suppress PTH release.
by the proximal tubule. Secretion of FGF-23 is stimulated by sustained hyperphosphatemia, PTH, and calcitriol. Activating mutations in the FGF23 gene cause hypophosphatemia, low plasma calcitriol, and rickets/osteomalacia, whereas inactivating mutations cause hyperphosphatemia, high calcitriol levels, and calcifications in the soft tissue.

## Regulation of Urinary Phosphate Excretion

Several hormones and factors regulate urinary $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion (Table 36.3 and Fig. 36.19). Increased plasma $\left[\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right]$ reduces $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$and therefore increases PTH levels, which increases renal $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion. PTH inhibits $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ reabsorption by the proximal tubule and thereby increases $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion. PTH
reduces $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ reabsorption by stimulating endocytic removal of $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ cotransporters from the brush border membrane in proximal tubular cells. Increased plasma $\left[\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right]$ also increases FGF-23, which inhibits $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ reabsorption and calcitriol production by the proximal tubule. Elevated plasma $\left[\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right]$ directly suppresses calcitriol production, which decreases intestinal $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ reabsorption. Dietary $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ intake also regulates $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion by mechanisms unrelated to changes in PTH levels. $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ loading increases excretion, whereas $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ depletion decreases it. Changes in dietary $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ intake modulate $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ transport by altering the transport rate and the number of $\mathrm{Na}^{+} /$ $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}} \mathrm{Ila}$ and IIc cotransporters in the apical membrane of the proximal tubule.

ECF volume affects $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion. ECF expansion enhances $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion by: (1) increasing GFR and thus the filtered amount of $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}} ;(2)$ decreasing the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$-coupled reabsorption, which reduces ECF volume; and (3) reducing plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$, thereby increasing PTH, which inhibits $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ reabsorption in the proximal tubule. Acid-base balance also influences $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion. Chronic acidemia increases $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion, and chronic alkalemia decreases it. These effects of acid-base status, like the effect of PTH, are mediated by altered expression of the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ cotransporters in the apical membrane. Metabolic acidosis increases the secretion of glucocorticoids, which inhibit $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ reabsorption by the proximal tubule and increase renal $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion. This inhibition, together with the direct effect of acidosis on $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ reabsorption by the proximal
tubule, enables the DT and collecting duct to secrete more $\mathrm{H}^{+}$as titratable acid and to generate more $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$because $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ is an important urinary buffer. Growth hormone decreases $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion.

## IN THE CLINIC

Klotho is highly expressed in the early DT of the kidney. Klotho knockout mice have a phenotype that resembles chronic kidney disease (CKD), including soft tissue calcification, hyperphosphatemia, and elevated plasma FGF-23. Klotho exists as a membrane-bound and a soluble protein. The membrane-bound form is a coreceptor for FGF-23, thus Klotho promotes $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion by the kidneys and reduces serum levels of calcitriol. Soluble circulating Klotho affects ion transport, Wnt signaling, and FGF-23-dependent PTH synthesis, and inhibits the renin-angiotensin axis. Klotho may be a biomarker for CKD, and its deficiency may contribute to development of CKD. Moreover, experimental data also suggest that Klotho therapy may slow the progression of CKD.

## Integrative Review of Parathyroid Hormone and Calcitriol on $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ Homeostasis

As summarized in Fig. 36.20, PTH regulates $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ homeostasis. Hypocalcemia is the major stimulus of PTH secretion. PTH causes bone resorption, increases urinary $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion, decreases urinary $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$excretion, and stimulates production of calcitriol, which stimulates intestinal $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ absorption. Because changes in $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ handling in bone, the GI tract, and kidneys tend to balance out, PTH increases plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$while having little effect on plasma $\left[\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right]$. Overall, a rise in PTH levels in response to hypocalcemia returns plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$to normal. Hypercalcemia has the opposite effect.

Calcitriol plays an important role in $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ homeostasis (Fig. 36.21). The net effect of calcitriol is to increase plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$and $\left[\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right]$. Thus the major stimuli of calcitriol production are hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia. The primary action of calcitriol is to stimulate $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ absorption from the GI tract. To a lesser degree, calcitriol acts with PTH to decrease renal $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$ excretion. Calcitriol may enhance the bone resorptive effect of PTH to release $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ from bone during a $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$deficient diet.

## IN THE CLINIC

In the absence of glucocorticoids (e.g., in Addison's disease), excretion of $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ is depressed, as is the ability of the kidneys to excrete titratable acid and to generate new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$. Growth hormone increases reabsorption of $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ by the proximal tubule. As a result, children are in positive $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ balance and have a higher plasma $\left[\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right]$ than adults, and the elevated $\left[\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right]$ is important for bone formation and growth.
