# Key Concepts 

1. $\mathrm{K}^{+}$homeostasis is maintained by the kidneys, which adjust $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion to match dietary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$intake, and by insulin, epinephrine, aldosterone, AVP, and glucocorticoids, which regulate the distribution of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$between the ICF and ECF and the renal $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion. Other conditions, such as cell lysis, exercise, changes in acid-base balance and plasma osmolality, affect $\mathrm{K}^{+}$homeostasis and plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$.
2. Excretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$by the kidneys is determined by the rate and direction of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$transport by the DT and CCD. Secretion of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$by these tubular segments is regulated by plasma $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$, aldosterone, and AVP. Changes in tubular fluid flow and acid-base balance alter $\mathrm{K}^{+}$excretion by the kidneys. In $\mathrm{K}^{+}$-depleted states, $\mathrm{K}^{+}$secretion is inhibited and its reabsorption increased by the DT and CCD.
3. The kidneys, in conjunction with the GI tract and bone, regulate plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$and $\left[\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right]$.
4. Plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$is regulated by PTH and calcitriol. Calcitonin is not a major regulatory hormone in humans. $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$ excretion by the kidneys is regulated by PTH, plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$, and calcitriol and is altered by changes in acidbase status, ECF volume, and plasma $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$.
5. $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$reabsorption is stimulated by PTH and calcitriol acting in the TAL and DT, and by elevated plasma $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{++}\right]$.
6. Plasma $\left[\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right]$ is regulated by PTH, FGF-23, and calcitriol. $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion is regulated by PTH, FGF-23, dietary $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$, and growth hormone and is altered by acid-base dysregulation, ECF expansion, and glucocorticoids.

# Role of the Kidneys in the Regulation of Acid-Base Balance 

## LEARNING OBJECTIVES

Upon completion of this chapter the student should be able to answer the following questions:

1. How does $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$operate as a buffer, and why is it an important buffer of the extracellular fluid?
2. How does metabolism of food produce acid and alkali, and what effect does the composition of the diet have on systemic acid-base balance?
3. What is the difference between volatile and nonvolatile acids, and what is net endogenous acid production (NEAP)?
4. How do the kidneys and lungs contribute to systemic acid-base balance, and what is renal net acid excretion (RNAE)?
5. Why are urinary buffers necessary for excretion of acid by the kidneys?
6. What are the mechanisms for $\mathrm{H}^{+}$transport in the various segments of the nephron, and how are these mechanisms regulated?
7. How do the various segments of the nephron contribute to the process of reabsorbing the filtered $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$?
8. How do the kidneys produce new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$?
9. How is ammonium produced by the kidneys, and how does its excretion contribute to renal acid excretion?
10. What are the major mechanisms by which the body defends itself against changes in acid-base balance?
11. What are the differences between simple metabolic and respiratory acid-base disorders, and how are they differentiated by arterial blood gas measurements?

The concentration of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$in body fluids is low compared with that of other ions. For example, $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$is present at a concentration some 3 million times greater than that of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$ $\left(\left[\mathrm{Na}^{+}\right]=140 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L} ;\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]=40 \mathrm{nEq} / \mathrm{L}\right)$. Because of the low $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$of the body fluids, it is commonly expressed as the negative logarithm, or pH .

Virtually all cellular, tissue, and organ processes are sensitive to pH . Indeed, life cannot exist outside of a range of extracellular fluid (ECF) pH from 6.8 to 7.8 $\left(160-16 \mathrm{nEq} / \mathrm{L}\right.$ of $\left.\mathrm{H}^{+}\right)$. Normally the pH of ECF is maintained between 7.35 and 7.45 . The pH of intracellular
fluid (ICF) is slightly lower (7.1-7.2) but is also tightly regulated.

Each day, acid and alkali are ingested in the diet. Also, cellular metabolism produces a number of substances that have an impact on the pH of body fluids. Without appropriate mechanisms to deal with this daily acid and alkali load and thereby maintain acid-base balance, many processes necessary for life could not occur. This chapter reviews the maintenance of whole-body acid-base balance. Although the emphasis is on the role of the kidneys in this process, the roles of the lungs and liver are also considered. In addition the impact of diet and cellular metabolism on acid-base balance is presented. Finally, disorders of acid-base balance are considered, primarily to illustrate the physiological processes involved. Throughout this chapter, acid is defined as any substance that adds $\mathrm{H}^{+}$to body fluids, whereas alkali is defined as a substance that removes $\mathrm{H}^{+}$from body fluids.

## The $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$Buffer System

Bicarbonate $\left(\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right)$is an important buffer of the ECF. With a normal plasma $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$of 23 to $25 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$ and a volume of 14 L (for a $70-\mathrm{kg}$ individual) the ECF can potentially buffer 350 mEq of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$. The $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$buffer system differs from the other buffer systems of the body (e.g., phosphate) because it is regulated by both the lungs and kidneys. This is best appreciated by considering the following reaction:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\text { Equation } 37.1 \\
\mathrm{CO}_{2}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \leftrightarrows \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{CO}_{3} \leftrightarrows \mathrm{H}^{+}+\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}
\end{gathered}
$$

As indicated the first reaction (hydration/dehydration of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ ) is the rate-limiting step. This normally slow reaction is greatly accelerated in the presence of carbonic anhydrase. ${ }^{2}$ The second reaction, ionization of $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{CO}_{3}$ to $\mathrm{H}^{+}$and $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$, is virtually instantaneous.

    $$

$$

\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]=\frac{24 \times \mathrm{PCO}_{2}}{\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]}
$$

Inspection of Eqs. 37.3 and 37.4 shows that pH and $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$vary when either $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$or $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ is altered. Disturbances of acid-base balance that result from a change in $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$are termed metabolic acid-base disorders, whereas those resulting from a change in $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ are termed respiratory
acid-base disorders. These disorders are considered in more detail in a subsequent section. The kidneys are primarily responsible for regulating the $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$of ECF , whereas the lungs control the $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$.

## Overview of Acid-Base Balance

The diet of humans contains many constituents that are either acid or alkali. In addition, cellular metabolism produces acid and alkali. Finally, alkali is normally lost each day in feces. As described later, although diet dependent, the net effect of these processes is the addition of acid to body fluids. For acid-base balance to be maintained, acid must be excreted from the body at a rate equivalent to its addition. If acid addition exceeds excretion, acidosis results. Conversely, if acid excretion exceeds addition, alkalosis results.

As summarized in Fig. 37.1, the major constituents of the diet are carbohydrates and fats. When tissue perfusion is adequate, $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ is available to tissues, and insulin is present at normal levels, carbohydrates and fats are metabolized to $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ and $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$. On a daily basis, 15 to 20 moles of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ are generated through this process. Normally this large quantity of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ is effectively eliminated from the body by the lungs. Therefore, this metabolically derived $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ has no impact on acid-base balance. $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ is usually termed volatile acid because it has the potential to generate $\mathrm{H}^{+}$after hydration with $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$ (see Eq. 37.1). Acid not derived directly from hydration of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ is termed nonvolatile acid (e.g., lactic acid).

The cellular metabolism of other dietary constituents also has an impact on acid-base balance. For example,

cysteine and methionine, sulfur-containing amino acids, yield sulfuric acid when metabolized, whereas hydrochloric acid results from metabolism of lysine, arginine, and histidine. A portion of this nonvolatile acid load is offset by production of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$through metabolism of the amino acids aspartate and glutamate. On average the metabolism of dietary amino acids yields net nonvolatile acid production. Metabolism of certain organic anions (e.g., citrate) results in production of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$, which offsets nonvolatile acid production to some degree. Overall, in individuals ingesting a meat-containing diet, acid production exceeds $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$production. In contrast, a vegetarian diet produces less nonvolatile acid. In addition to the metabolically derived acids and alkalis, the foods ingested contain acid and alkali. For example, the presence of phosphate $\left(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{PO}_{4}^{-}\right)$in ingested food increases the dietary acid load. Finally, during digestion, some $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$is normally lost in feces. This loss is equivalent to the addition of nonvolatile acid to the body. In an individual ingesting a meatcontaining diet, dietary intake, cellular metabolism, and fecal $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$loss result in addition of approximately 0.7 to $1.0 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{kg}$ body weight of nonvolatile acid to the body each day ( $50-100 \mathrm{mEq} /$ day for most adults). This acid, referred to as net endogenous acid production (NEAP), results in an equivalent loss of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$from the body that must be replaced.

## IN THE CLINIC

When insulin levels are normal, carbohydrates and fats are completely metabolized to $\mathrm{CO}_{2}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$. However, if insulin levels are abnormally low (e.g., diabetes mellitus), cellular metabolism leads to production of several organic ketoacids (e.g., $\beta$-hydroxybutyric acid and acetoacetic acid from fatty acids).

In the absence of adequate levels of $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ (hypoxia), anaerobic metabolism by cells can also lead to production of organic acids (e.g., lactic acid) rather than $\mathrm{CO}_{2}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$. This frequently occurs in normal individuals during vigorous exercise. Poor tissue perfusion, such as occurs with reduced cardiac output, can also lead to anaerobic metabolism by cells and thus to acidosis. In these conditions the organic acids accumulate and the pH of body fluids decreases (acidosis). Treatment (e.g., administration of insulin in the case of diabetes) or improved delivery of adequate levels of $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ to tissues (e.g., in the case of poor tissue perfusion) results in the metabolism of these organic acids to $\mathrm{CO}_{2}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$, which consumes $\mathrm{H}^{+}$and thereby helps correct the acid-base disorder.

Nonvolatile acids do not circulate throughout the body but are immediately neutralized by the $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$in ECF.

## Equation 37.5

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}+2 \mathrm{NaHCO}_{3} \leftrightarrow \mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}+2 \mathrm{CO}_{2}+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \\
\text { Equation 37.6 } \\
\mathrm{HCl}+\mathrm{NaHCO}_{3} \leftrightarrow \mathrm{NaCl}+\mathrm{CO}_{2}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}
\end{gathered}
$$

This neutralization process yields the $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$salts of the strong acids and removes $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$from the ECF. Thus
$\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$minimizes the effect of these strong acids on the pH of ECF. As noted previously, ECF contains approximately 350 mEq of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$. If this $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$were not replenished, the daily production of nonvolatile acids ( $\approx 70 \mathrm{mEq} /$ day) would deplete the ECF of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$within 5 days. To maintain acid-base balance the kidneys must replenish the $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$lost by neutralization of the nonvolatile acids, a process termed renal net acid excretion (RNAE).

## Net Acid Excretion by the Kidneys

Under steady-state conditions, NEAP must equal RNAE to maintain acid-base balance. Although NEAP varies from individual to individual and from day to day in anyone individual, it is not regulated. Instead, the kidneys regulate RNAE to match NEAP and in so doing replenish the $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$(new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$) lost by neutralization of nonvolatile acids. In addition, the kidneys must prevent the loss of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$in urine. This latter task is quantitatively more important because the filtered load of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$is approximately $4320 \mathrm{mEq} /$ day ( $24 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L} \times 180 \mathrm{~L} /$ day $=4320 \mathrm{mEq} /$ day $)$, compared with only 50 to $100 \mathrm{mEq} /$ day needed to balance NEAP.

Both reabsorption of filtered $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$and excretion of acid are accomplished via $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion by the nephrons. Thus, in a single day the nephrons must secrete approximately 4390 mEq of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$into the tubular fluid. Most of the secreted $\mathrm{H}^{+}$serves to reabsorb the filtered load of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$. Only 50 to 100 mEq of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$, an amount equivalent to NEAP, is excreted in urine. As a result of this acid excretion, urine is normally acidic.

The kidneys cannot excrete urine more acidic than pH 4.0 to 4.5 . Even at a pH of 4.0 , only $0.1 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$ of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$can be excreted. Therefore, to excrete sufficient acid, the kidneys excrete $\mathrm{H}^{+}$with urinary buffers such as phosphate $\left(\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right) .{ }^{6}$ Other constituents of urine can also serve as buffers (e.g., creatinine), although their role is less important than $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$. Collectively the various urinary buffers are termed titratable acid. This term is derived from the method by which these buffers are quantitated in the laboratory. Typically, alkali $\left(\mathrm{OH}^{-}\right)$is added to a urine sample to titrate its pH to that of plasma (i.e., 7.4). The amount of alkali added is equal to the $\mathrm{H}^{+}$titrated by these urine buffers and is termed titratable acid.

Excretion of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$as a titratable acid is insufficient to balance NEAP. An additional and important mechanism by which the kidneys contribute to maintenance of acid-base balance is through synthesis and excretion of ammonium $\left(\mathbf{N H}_{4}{ }^{+}\right)$. The mechanisms involved in this process are discussed in more detail later in this chapter. With regard to renal regulation of acid-base balance, each $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$excreted in urine results in the return of one $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$to the systemic circulation, which replenishes the $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$lost during neutralization of the nonvolatile acids. Thus, production and excretion of $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$, like excretion of titratable acid, is equivalent to excretion of acid by the kidneys.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{6}$ The titration reaction is: $\mathrm{HPO}_{4}{ }^{2-}+\mathrm{H}^{+} \leftrightarrow \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{PO}_{4}^{-}$. This reaction has a pK of approximately 6.8 .

In brief the kidneys contribute to acid-base homeostasis by reabsorbing the filtered load of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$and excreting an amount of acid equivalent to NEAP. This process can be quantitated as follows:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\text { Equation } 37.7 \\
\mathrm{RNAE}=\left(\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}} \times \dot{\mathrm{V}}\right)+\left(\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{TA}} \times \dot{\mathrm{V}}\right)-\left(\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}} \times \dot{\mathrm{V}}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

where $\left(\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}}+\dot{\mathrm{V}}\right)$ and $\left(\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{TA}}+\dot{\mathrm{V}}\right)$ are the rates of excretion (mEq/day) of $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$and titratable acid (TA), and $\left(\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}}+\dot{\mathrm{V}}\right)$ is the amount of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$lost in urine (equivalent to adding $\mathrm{H}^{+}$to the body). ${ }^{+}$Again, maintenance of acid-base balance means that net acid excretion must equal nonvolatile acid production. Under most conditions, very little $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$is excreted in urine. Thus net acid excretion essentially reflects titratable acid and $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$excretion. Quantitatively, titratable acid accounts for approximately one-third and $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$for two-thirds of RNAE.

## $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$Reabsorption Along the Nephron

As indicated by Eq. 37.7, net acid excretion is maximized when little or no $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$is excreted in urine. Indeed, under most circumstances, very little $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$appears in urine. Because $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$is freely filtered at the glomerulus, approximately $4320 \mathrm{mEq} /$ day is delivered to the nephrons and is then reabsorbed. Fig. 37.2 summarizes the contribution of each nephron segment to reabsorption of filtered $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$.

The proximal tubule reabsorbs the largest portion of the filtered load of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$. Fig. 37.3 summarizes the primary transport processes involved. $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion across the apical membrane of the cell occurs by both a $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{H}^{+}$antiporter and $\mathrm{H}^{+}$-ATPase (V-type). The $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{H}^{+}$antiporter (NHE3) is the predominant pathway for $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion (accounts for $\approx$ two-thirds
![be59594790948](be59594790948.jpg)

- Fig. 37.3 Cellular mechanism for reabsorption of filtered $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$by cells of the proximal tubule. Only the primary $\mathrm{H}^{+}$and $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$transporters are shown. ATP, Adenosine triphosphate; CA, carbonic anhydrase.


[^0]:    ${ }^{+}$This equation ignores the small amount of free $\mathrm{H}^{+}$excreted in urine. As already noted, urine with a $\mathrm{pH} \approx 4.0$ contains only $0.1 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$ of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$.

of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$reabsorption) and uses the lumen-to-cell $\left[\mathrm{Na}^{+}\right]$ gradient to drive this process (i.e., secondary active secretion of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$). Within the cell, $\mathrm{H}^{+}$and $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$are produced in a reaction catalyzed by carbonic anhydrase (CA-II). The $\mathrm{H}^{+}$is secreted into the tubular fluid, whereas the $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$exits the cell across the basolateral membrane and returns to the peritubular blood. $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$movement out of the cell across the basolateral membrane is coupled to other ions. The majority of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$exits via a symporter that couples the efflux of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$with $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$(sodium bicarbonate symporter, NBC1). Some $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$exits the cell by other transporters, but they are not as important as the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$symporter. As noted in Fig. 37.3, carbonic anhydrase (CA-IV) is also present in the brush border and basolateral membrane of the cell. The brush border enzyme catalyzes dehydration of $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{CO}_{3}$ in the luminal fluid, whereas the enzyme localized to basolateral membrane facilitates $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$exit from the cell. The movement of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ into and out of the cell occurs via AQP1, which is localized to both the luminal and basolateral membranes.

The cellular mechanism for $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$reabsorption by the thick ascending limb (TAL) of the loop of Henle is very similar to that in the proximal tubule. $\mathrm{H}^{+}$is secreted by a $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{H}^{+}$ antiporter and $\mathrm{H}^{+}$-ATPase. Like in the proximal tubule, the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{H}^{+}$antiporter (NHE3) is the predominant pathway for $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion. $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$exit from the cell involves both a $\mathrm{Na}^{+} /$ $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$symporter (NBC1) and a $\mathrm{Cl}^{-} / \mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$antiporter (anion exchanger, AE-2). Some $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$may also exit the cell through $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$channels present in the basolateral membrane.

The distal tubule ${ }^{9}$ and collecting duct reabsorb the small amount of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$that escapes reabsorption by the proximal tubule and loop of Henle. Fig. 37.4 shows the cellular mechanism of $\mathrm{H}^{+} / \mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$transport by the intercalated cells located within these segments (see also Chapter 34).

One type of intercalated cell secretes $\mathrm{H}^{+}$(reabsorbs $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$) and is called the $A$ - or $\alpha$-intercalated cell. Within this cell, $\mathrm{H}^{+}$and $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$are produced by hydration of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$; this reaction is catalyzed by carbonic anhydrase (CA-II). $\mathrm{H}^{+}$ is secreted into the tubular fluid via two mechanisms. The first involves an apical membrane $\mathrm{H}^{+}$-ATPase (V-type). The second couples secretion of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$with reabsorption of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$via an $\mathrm{H}^{+}-\mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase similar to those found in the stomach and colon (HK $\alpha 1$ and HK $\alpha 2$ ). $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$exits the cell across the basolateral membrane in exchange for $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$(via a $\mathrm{Cl}^{-} / \mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$ antiporter, $\mathrm{AE}-1$ ) and enters the peritubular capillary blood.

A second population of intercalated cells secretes $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$ rather than $\mathrm{H}^{+}$into the tubular fluid (also called $B$ - or $\beta$-intercalated cells). ${ }^{7}$ In these cells the $\mathrm{H}^{+}$-ATPase (V-type) is located in the basolateral membrane and the $\mathrm{Cl}^{-} / \mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$ antiporter is located in the apical membrane (see Fig. 37.4).

[^0]However, the apical membrane $\mathrm{Cl}^{-} / \mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$antiporter is different from the one found in the basolateral membrane of the $\mathrm{H}^{+}$-secreting intercalated cells and has been identified as pendrin. The activity of the $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$-secreting intercalated cell is increased during metabolic alkalosis, when the kidneys must excrete excess $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$. However, under most conditions (e.g., ingestion of a meat-containing diet) $\mathrm{H}^{+}$ secretion predominates in these segments. ${ }^{7}$

The apical membrane of collecting duct cells is not very permeable to $\mathrm{H}^{+}$, and thus the pH of tubular fluid can become quite acidic. Indeed, the most acidic tubular fluid along the nephron ( $\mathrm{pH}=4.0-4.5$ ) is produced there. In comparison the permeability of the proximal tubule to $\mathrm{H}^{+}$and $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$is much higher, and the tubular fluid pH falls to only 6.5 in this segment. As explained later the ability of the collecting duct to lower the pH of the tubular fluid is critically important for excretion of urinary titratable acids and $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$.

## Regulation of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$Secretion

A number of factors influence secretion of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$and thus reabsorption of filtered $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$by the cells of the nephron. From a physiological perspective the primary factor that regulates $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion by the nephron is a change in systemic acid-base balance. Thus acidosis stimulates RNAE, whereas RNAE is reduced during alkalosis.

## 3 AT THE CELLULAR LEVEL

Cells of the kidney express receptors that monitor acid-base status and therefore play a critical role in regulating $\mathrm{H}^{+}$and $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$transporters along the nephron (Fig. 37.5). For example, a G protein-coupled $\mathrm{H}^{+}$receptor (GPCR-GPR4) has been localized to the collecting duct. Activation of this receptor by an increase in ECF $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$stimulates $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion. Also in the collecting duct, $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$-secreting intercalated cells (B- or $\beta$-ICs) express a basolateral insulin-related receptor (IRR) that is a tyrosine kinase. It is activated by an increase in ECF $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$ and stimulates $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$secretion by the cell. A soluble adenylyl cyclase (sAC) regulated by intracellular $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$appears to also play a role in regulating collecting duct $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion. In the proximal tubule, basolateral membrane receptor tyrosine kinases (ErbB1 and ErbB2) sense changes in ECF $\mathrm{PcO}_{2}$. Activation of these receptors by an increase in $\mathrm{PcO}_{2}$ results in generation of angiotensin II, which, acting from the lumen via AT-1A receptors, stimulates $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion $/ \mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$reabsorption. Also in the proximal tubule, the nonreceptor tyrosine kinase (Pyk2) senses intracellular $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$. When it is activated by an increase in intracellular $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right], \mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion $/ \mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$reabsorption is stimulated. Finally, the gating of several ion channels (e.g., the renal outer medullary $\mathrm{K}^{+}$channel [ROMK]) is affected by changes in either ECF or ICF pH . These too have the potential to serve as cellular acid-base sensors.

The response of the kidneys to changes in acid-base balance includes both immediate changes in the activity and/or number of transporters in the membrane and longer-term changes in the synthesis of transporters. For example, with metabolic acidosis, $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion is stimulated by multiple
mechanisms, depending on the particular nephron segment. First, the decrease in intracellular pH that occurs with acidosis will create a more favorable cell-to-tubular fluid $\mathrm{H}^{+}$ gradient and thereby make secretion of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$across the apical membrane more energetically favorable. Second, the

ATP, Adenosine triphosphate; cAMP, cyclic adenosine monophosphate; GPCR, G protein-coupled receptor; IRR, insulin receptor-related receptor; Pyk2, nonreceptor tyrosine kinase; sAC, soluble adenylyl cyclase. decrease in pH may lead to allosteric changes in transport proteins, thereby altering their kinetics. Lastly, transporters may be shuttled to the membrane from intracellular vesicles. With long-term acidosis the abundance of transporters increases, either by increased transcription of appropriate transporter genes or by increased translation of transporter mRNA.


## 3 AT THE CELLULAR LEVEL

In the proximal tubule, metabolic acidosis increases the transport kinetics of the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{H}^{+}$antiporter ( $\mathrm{NHCO}_{3}$ ) and increases apical membrane expression of the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{H}^{+}$ antiporter, $\mathrm{H}^{+}$-ATPase, and the basolateral $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / 3 \mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$ symporter (NBCe1). In the collecting duct, acidosis leads to exocytic insertion of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$-ATPase into the apical membrane of intercalated cells. With long-term acidosis the abundance of key acid-base transporters is increased in the proximal tubule (NHE3 and NBCe1) and in collecting duct intercalated cells ( $\mathrm{H}^{+}$-ATPase and AE 1 ). Lastly, acidosis decreases expression of the $\mathrm{Cl}^{-} / \mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$ antiporter pendrin in $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$-secreting intercalated cells.

Although some of the effects just described may be attributable directly to acidosis, many of these changes in cellular $\mathrm{H}^{+}$transport are mediated by hormones or other factors. Three known mediators of the renal response to acidosis are endothelin, cortisol, and angiotensin II. Endothelin (ET-1) is produced by endothelial and proximal tubule cells. With acidosis, ET-1 secretion is enhanced. In the proximal tubule, ET-1 stimulates phosphorylation and subsequent insertion of the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{H}^{+}$antiporter into the apical membrane, and
insertion of the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / 3 \mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$symporter into the basolateral membrane. ET-1 may mediate the response to acidosis in other nephron segments as well. Acidosis also stimulates secretion of the glucocorticoid hormone cortisol by the adrenal cortex. Cortisol increases the abundance of the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} /$ $\mathrm{H}^{+}$antiporter and $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / 3 \mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$symporter in the proximal tubule. Angiotensin II is produced in proximal tubule cells in response to acidosis. It is secreted into the tubular fluid, where it binds to the angiotensin I receptor and thereby stimulates $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion $/ \mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$reabsorption by the proximal tubule. Both cortisol and angiotensin II also stimulate production and secretion of $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$by the proximal tubule, which as described later is an important component of the kidney's response to acidosis.

Acidosis also stimulates secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH inhibits phosphate $\left(\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}\right)$ reabsorption by the proximal tubule (see Chapter 36). In so doing, more $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ is delivered to the distal nephron, where it serves as a urinary buffer and thus increases the capacity of the kidneys to excrete titratable acid.

The response of the kidneys to alkalosis is less well characterized. RNAE is decreased because of increased urinary $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$excretion and because excretion of titratable acid and $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$is reduced. The factors that regulate this response are not well characterized.

Other factors not necessarily related to maintaining acidbase balance can influence secretion of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$by the cells of the nephron. Because a significant $\mathrm{H}^{+}$transporter in the nephron is the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{H}^{+}$antiporter, factors that alter $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$ reabsorption can secondarily affect $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion. For example, with volume contraction (negative $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$balance), $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$ reabsorption by the nephron is increased (see Chapter 35),

including reabsorption of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$via the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{H}^{+}$antiporter. As a result, $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion is enhanced. This occurs by several mechanisms. One mechanism involves the renin-angioten-sin-aldosterone system, which is activated by volume contraction. As noted earlier, angiotensin II acts on the proximal tubule to stimulate the apical membrane $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{H}^{+}$antiporter as well as the basolateral $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / 3 \mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$symporter. To a lesser degree, angiotensin II stimulates $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion in the TAL of Henle's loop and the early portion of the distal tubule, a process also mediated by the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{H}^{+}$antiporter. Aldosterone's primary action on the distal tubule and collecting duct is to stimulate $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption by principal cells (see Chapter 34). However, it also stimulates intercalated cells in these segments to secrete $\mathrm{H}^{+}$. This effect is both indirect and direct. By stimulating $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption by principal cells, aldosterone hyperpolarizes the transepithelial voltage (i.e., the lumen becomes more electrically negative). This change in transepithelial voltage then facilitates secretion of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$by intercalated cells. In addition to this indirect effect, aldosterone (and angiotensin II) act directly on intercalated cells to stimulate $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion via $\mathrm{H}^{+}$-ATPase and $\mathrm{H}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase.

Another mechanism by which ECF volume (ECFV) contraction enhances $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion $\left(\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}\right.$reabsorption) is through changes in peritubular capillary Starling forces. As described in Chapters 34 and 35, ECFV contraction alters the peritubular capillary Starling forces such that overall proximal tubule reabsorption is enhanced. With this enhanced reabsorption, more of the filtered load of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$ is reabsorbed.

Potassium balance influences secretion of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$by the proximal tubule. Hypokalemia stimulates and hyperkalemia inhibits $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion. It is thought that $\mathrm{K}^{+}$-induced changes in intracellular pH are responsible at least in part for this effect. Hypokalemia acidifies the cells as intracellular $\mathrm{K}^{+}$is exchanged for $\mathrm{H}^{+}$, whereas hyperkalemia alkalinizing cells as intracellular $\mathrm{H}^{+}$is exchanged for $\mathrm{K}^{+}$. Hypokalemia also stimulates $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion by the collecting duct. This occurs as a result of increased expression of the $\mathrm{H}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$-ATPase in intercalated cells.

## Formation of New $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$

As discussed previously, reabsorption of the filtered load of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$is important for maximizing RNAE. However, $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$reabsorption alone does not replenish the $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$ lost during neutralization of the nonvolatile acids produced during metabolism. To maintain acid-base balance, the kidneys must replace this lost $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$with new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$. Generation of new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$occurs by excretion of titratable acid and by synthesis and excretion of $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$.

Production of new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$as a result of titratable acid excretion is depicted in Fig. 37.6. Because of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$reabsorption by the proximal tubule and loop of Henle, fluid reaching the distal tubule and collecting duct normally contains little $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$. Thus, when $\mathrm{H}^{+}$is secreted it will combine with non- $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$buffers (primarily $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{r}}$ ) and be excreted as titratable acid. Because the $\mathrm{H}^{+}$was produced inside the cell from hydration of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$, a $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$is also produced.

- Fig. 37.7 Production, transport, and excretion of $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$by the nephron. Glutamine is metabolized to $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$ and $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$in the proximal tubule. The $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$is secreted into the lumen, and the $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$enters the blood. The secreted $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$is reabsorbed in Henle's loop, primarily by the thick ascending limb, and accumulates in the medullary interstitium. $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ is secreted by the collecting duct via rhesus glycoproteins, and $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion traps $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$in the lumen. This $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$is returned to the ECF as new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$. As noted, $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ excretion increases with acidosis. However, even with increased $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ available for titratable acid formation, this response is insufficient to generate the required amount of new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$. The remainder of new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$generation occurs as a result of $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$generation and excretion.
$\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$is produced by the kidneys, and its synthesis and subsequent excretion adds $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$to ECF. Importantly, this process is regulated in response to the acid-base requirements of the body.
$\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$is produced in the kidneys via metabolism of glutamine. Essentially the kidneys metabolize glutamine, excrete $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$, and add $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$to the body. However, formation of new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$via this process depends on the kidneys' ability to excrete $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$in urine. If $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$is not excreted in urine but instead enters the systemic circulation, it is converted into urea by the liver. This conversion process generates $\mathrm{H}^{+}$, which is then buffered by $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$. Thus, production of urea from renal-generated $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$consumes $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$and negates formation of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$through synthesis and excretion of $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$by the kidneys. However, normally the kidneys excrete $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$in urine and thereby produce new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$.

The process by which the kidneys excrete $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$is complex. Fig. 37.7 illustrates the essential features of this process. $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$is produced from glutamine in the cells of the proximal tubule, a process termed ammoniagenesis. Each glutamine molecule produces two molecules of $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$and the divalent anion 2-oxoglutarate ${ }^{2-}$. Metabolism of this
anion ultimately provides two molecules of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-} . \mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$ exits the cell across the basolateral membrane and enters the peritubular blood as new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-} . \mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$exits the cell across the apical membrane and enters the tubular fluid. The primary mechanism for $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$secretion into the tubular fluid involves the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{H}^{+}$antiporter, with $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$substituting for $\mathrm{H}^{+}$. In addition, some $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ can diffuse out of the cell into the tubular fluid, where it is protonated to $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$.

A significant portion of the $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$secreted by the proximal tubule is reabsorbed by the loop of Henle. The TAL is the primary site of this $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$reabsorption, with $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$ substituting for $\mathrm{K}^{+}$on the $1 \mathrm{Na}^{+} / 1 \mathrm{~K}^{+} / 2 \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$symporter. In addition, the lumen-positive transepithelial voltage in this segment drives paracellular reabsorption of $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$.

The $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$reabsorbed by the TAL of the loop of Henle accumulates in the medullary interstitium. From there it is then secreted into the tubular fluid by the collecting duct.

The cells of the collecting duct express two $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ membrane transporters known as Rhesus (Rh) glycoproteins (RhBG and RhCG). ${ }^{2}$ RhBG is present in the basolateral membrane of $\mathrm{H}+$-secreting intercalated cells and principal cells, and RhCG is present in both the apical and basolateral membranes of these cells. As depicted in Fig. 37.7, $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ is transported across the collecting duct, a process traditionally termed nonionic diffusion. The secreted $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$ is protonated in the tubule lumen as a result of intercalated $\mathrm{H}^{+}$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ Both RhBG and RhCG transport $\mathrm{NH}_{3}$. There is some evidence that RhBG may also transport some $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$.

secretion. Because the apical membrane has a low permeability to $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$it is effectively trapped in the tubular lumen, a process traditionally termed diffusion trapping.
$\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion by the collecting duct is critical for excretion of $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$. If collecting duct $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion is inhibited, the $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$reabsorbed by the TAL of Henle's loop will not be excreted in the urine. Instead, $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$will be returned to the systemic circulation, whereas described previously, it will be converted to urea by the liver and consume $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$in the process. New $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$is therefore produced during the metabolism of glutamine by cells of the proximal tubule. However, the overall process is not complete until the $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$ is excreted (i.e., production of urea from $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$by the liver is prevented). In the net, one new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$is returned to the systemic circulation for each $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$excreted in the urine. Accordingly, $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$excretion in urine can be used as a marker of glutamine metabolism in the proximal tubule.

## IN THE CLINIC

Assessing $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$excretion by the kidneys is done indirectly because assays of urine $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$are not routinely available. Consider, for example, the situation of metabolic acidosis, wherein the appropriate renal response is to increase net acid excretion. Accordingly, little or no $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$will appear in urine, urine will be acidic, and $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$excretion will be increased. To assess this, and especially the amount of $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$excreted, the "urinary net charge" or "urine anion gap" can be calculated by measuring urinary concentrations of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$, and $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$:

$$
\text { Urineaniongap }=\left(\left[\mathrm{Na}^{+}\right]+\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]\right) \cdot\left[\mathrm{Cl}^{-}\right]
$$

The concept of urine anion gap during a metabolic acidosis assumes that the major cations in urine are $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$, and $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$ and that the major anion is $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$(with urine $\mathrm{pH}<6.5$, virtually no $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$is present). The principle of electroneutrality denotes that the sum of the cations and anions in the urine should be equal. As a result, the urine anion gap will yield a negative value when $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$, an unmeasured cation, is being excreted. Note, that an anion gap does not actually exist-the number of cations and anions is equal. The calculated anion gap simply reflects the parameters that are measured, and $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$ is not routinely measured. Indeed, the absence of a urine anion gap or the existence of a positive value indicates a renal defect in $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$production and excretion.

An important feature of the renal $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$system is that it is regulated by systemic acid-base balance. As already described, cortisol levels increase with acidosis, as does angiotensin II secretion into the lumen of the proximal tubule. Both cortisol and angiotensin II stimulate ammoniagenesis (i.e., $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$production from glutamine). During systemic acidosis, the enzymes in the proximal tubule cell responsible for metabolism of glutamine are stimulated. This involves synthesis of new enzyme and requires several days for complete adaptation. With increased levels of these enzymes, $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$production is increased, allowing enhanced production of new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$. Conversely, glutamine metabolism is reduced with alkalosis. Acidosis also increases the abundance of RhBG and RhCG in the collecting duct, and thus, the ability to secrete $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$is also enhanced.

## Response to Acid-Base Disorders

The pH of the ECF is maintained within a very narrow range (7.35-7.45). ${ }^{5}$ Inspection of Eq. 37.3 shows that the pH of ECF varies when either $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$or $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ is altered. As already noted, disturbances of acid-base balance that result from a change in $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$of ECF are termed metabolic acid-base disorders, whereas those resulting from a change in $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ are termed respiratory acid-base disorders. The kidneys are primarily responsible for regulating $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$, whereas the lungs regulate $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$.

When an acid-base disturbance develops, the body uses several mechanisms to defend against the change in ECF pH . These defense mechanisms do not correct the acid-base disturbance but merely minimize the change in pH imposed by the disturbance. Restoration of the blood pH to its normal value requires correction of the underlying process or processes that produced the acid-base disorder. The body has three general mechanisms to defend against changes in body fluid pH produced by acid-base disturbances: (1) extracellular and intracellular buffering, (2) adjustments in blood $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ via alterations in the ventilatory rate of the lungs, and (3) adjustments in RNAE.

## Extracellular and Intracellular Buffers

The first line of defense against acid-base disorders is extracellular and intracellular buffering. The response of the extracellular buffers is virtually instantaneous, whereas the response to intracellular buffering is slower and can take several minutes.

Metabolic disorders that result from addition of nonvolatile acid or alkali to body fluids are buffered in both the extracellular and intracellular compartments. The $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$buffer system is the principal ECF buffer. When nonvolatile acid is added to body fluids (or alkali is lost from the body), $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$is consumed during the process of neutralizing the acid load, and the $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$of ECF is reduced. Conversely, when nonvolatile alkali is added to body fluids (or acid is lost from the body), $\mathrm{H}^{+}$is consumed, causing more $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$to be produced from the dissociation of $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{CO}_{3}$. Consequently, $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$increases.

Although the $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$buffer system is the principal ECF buffer, $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ and plasma proteins provide additional extracellular buffering. The combined action of the buffering processes for $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}, \mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$, and plasma protein accounts for approximately $50 \%$ of the buffering of a nonvolatile acid load and $70 \%$ of a nonvolatile alkali load. The remainder of the buffering under these two conditions occurs intracellularly. Intracellular buffering involves movement of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$into cells (during buffering of nonvolatile acid) or movement of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$out of cells (during buffering of nonvolatile alkali). $\mathrm{H}^{+}$is titrated inside the cell by $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}, \mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$, and the histidine groups on proteins.

Bone represents an additional source of extracellular buffering. However, with acidosis, buffering by bone results in its demineralization.

When respiratory acid-base disorders occur, the pH of body fluid changes as a result of alterations in $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$. Virtually all buffering in respiratory acid-base disorders occurs intracellularly. When $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ rises (respiratory acidosis), $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ moves into the cell, where it combines with $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$ to form $\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{CO}_{3} . \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{CO}_{3}$ then dissociates to $\mathrm{H}^{+}$and $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$. Some of the $\mathrm{H}^{+}$is buffered by cellular proteins, and $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$ exits the cell and raises the ECF $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$. This process is reversed when $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ is reduced (respiratory alkalosis). Under this condition the hydration reaction $\left(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}+\mathrm{CO}_{2} \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{CO}_{3}\right)$ is shifted to the left by the decrease in $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$. As a result the dissociation reaction $\left(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{CO}_{3} \mathrm{O} \mathrm{H}^{+}+\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right)$also shifts to the left, thereby reducing the ECF $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$.

## Respiratory Compensation

The lungs are the second line of defense against acid-base disorders. As indicated by the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation (see Eq. 37.2), changes in $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ alter the blood pH : a rise decreases the pH , and a reduction increases the pH .

The ventilatory rate determines the $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$. Increased ventilation decreases $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$, whereas decreased ventilation increases it (Fig. 37.8). The blood $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ and pH are important regulators of the ventilatory rate. Chemoreceptors located in the brainstem (ventral surface of the medulla) and periphery (carotid and aortic bodies) sense changes in $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ and $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$and alter the ventilatory rate appropriately. Thus, when metabolic acidosis occurs, a rise in the $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$(decrease in pH ) stimulates the ventilatory rate. Conversely, during metabolic alkalosis, a decreased $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$(increase in pH ) reduces the ventilatory rate. With maximal hyperventilation, the $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ can be reduced to approximately 10 mm Hg . Because hypoxia, a potent stimulator of ventilation, also develops with hypoventilation, the degree to which the $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ can be increased is limited. In an otherwise normal individual, hypoventilation cannot raise the $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ above
60 mm Hg . The respiratory response to metabolic acidbase disturbances may be initiated within minutes but may require several hours to complete.

## Renal Compensation

The third and final line of defense against acid-base disorders involves the kidneys. In response to an alteration in plasma pH and $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$, the kidneys make appropriate adjustments in the excretion of RNAE. The renal response may require several days to reach completion because it takes hours to days to increase the synthesis and activity of the proximal tubule enzymes involved in $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$production. In the case of acidosis (increased $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$or $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ ), the secretion of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$ by the nephron is stimulated and the entire filtered load of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$is reabsorbed. Titratable acid excretion is increased and production and excretion of $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$is also stimulated, and thus RNAE is increased (Fig. 37.9). The new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$ generated during the process of net acid excretion is added to the body, and the plasma $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$increases.

When metabolic alkalosis exists (decreased $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$), the filtered load of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$is increased (plasma $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$is elevated). With respiratory alkalosis (decreased $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ ), plasma $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$is decreased and thus the filtered load is decreased. In both conditions, secretion of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$by the nephron is inhibited. As a result, $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$excretion is increased. At the same time, excretion of both titratable acid and $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$ is decreased. Thus, RNAE is decreased and $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$appears in urine. Also, some $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$is secreted into urine by the $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$-secreting intercalated cells of the distal tubule and collecting duct. With enhanced excretion of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$, plasma $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$decreases.

## IN THE CLINIC

Loss of gastric contents from the body (e.g., vomiting, nasogastric suctioning) produces metabolic alkalosis secondary to the loss of HCl . If the loss of gastric fluid is significant, ECFV contraction occurs. Under this condition the kidneys cannot excrete sufficient quantities of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$to compensate for the metabolic alkalosis. The inability of the kidneys to excrete $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$is a result of the need to reduce $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$excretion to correct the ECFV contraction. As described previously (see Chapter 35 for details), the response of the kidneys to volume contraction is to reduce the glomerular filtration rate, which reduces the filtered load of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$, and to increase $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption along the nephron. Because a large amount of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption occurs via the $\mathrm{Na}^{+} / \mathrm{H}^{+}$antiporter, this results in an increase in $\mathrm{H}^{+}$ secretion $\left(\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right.$reabsorption) by the proximal tubule. In this setting the entire filtered load of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$is reabsorbed and new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$generation may even be enhanced. The latter response occurs because aldosterone, the levels of which are elevated in volume contraction, stimulates not only distal $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$reabsorption but also $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion by intercalated cells. This stimulation of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion generates new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$by enhancing titratable acid and $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$excretion. Thus, in individuals who lose gastric contents, metabolic alkalosis and paradoxically acidic urine characteristically occur. Correction of the alkalosis occurs only when euvolemia is reestablished.

## Simple Acid-Base Disorders

Table 37.1 summarizes the primary alterations and the subsequent compensatory or defense mechanisms of the various simple acid-base disorders. In all acid-base disorders the compensatory response does not correct the underlying disorder but simply reduces the magnitude of the change in pH . Correction of the acid-base disorder requires treatment of its cause.

## Types of Acid-Base Disorders

## Metabolic Acidosis

Metabolic acidosis is characterized by a decreased ECF $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$and pH . It can develop via the addition of
nonvolatile acid to the body (e.g., diabetic ketoacidosis), the loss of nonvolatile base (e.g., $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$loss caused by diarrhea), or failure of the kidneys to excrete titratable acid and $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$(e.g., renal failure). As previously described, the buffering of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$occurs in both the ECF and ICF compartments. When the pH falls, the respiratory centers are stimulated and the ventilatory rate is increased (respiratory compensation).

Finally, in metabolic acidosis, RNAE is increased. This occurs via elimination of all $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$from urine (enhanced reabsorption of filtered $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$) and via increased titratable acid and $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$excretion (enhanced production of new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$). If the process that initiated the acid-base disturbance is corrected, the enhanced RNAE will ultimately

return the pH and $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$to normal. After correction of the pH , the ventilatory rate also returns to normal.

## IN THE CLINIC

When nonvolatile acid is added to body fluids, as in diabetic ketoacidosis, the $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$increases ( pH decreases), and the $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$decreases. In addition, the concentration of the anion associated with the nonvolatile acid increases. This change in anion concentration provides a convenient way of analyzing the cause of a metabolic acidosis by calculating what is termed the anion gap. The anion gap represents the difference between the concentration of the major ECF cation $\left(\mathrm{Na}^{+}\right)$and the major ECF anions $\left(\mathrm{Cl}^{-}\right.$and $\left.\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right)$:

$$
\text { Aniongap }=\left[\mathrm{Na}^{+}\right]-\left(\left[\mathrm{Cl}^{-}\right]+\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]\right)
$$

Under normal conditions the anion gap ranges from 8 to $16 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$. It is important to recognize that an anion gap does not actually exist. All cations are balanced by anions. The gap simply reflects the parameters that are measured. In reality:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\mathrm{Na}^{+}\right]+\left[\text {Unmeasuredcations }\right]} \\
& =\left[\mathrm{Cl}^{-}\right]+\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]+\left[\text { Unmeasuredanions }\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

If the anion of the nonvolatile acid is $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$, the anion gap will be normal (i.e., the decrease in $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$is matched by an increase in $\left[\mathrm{Cl}^{-}\right]$). Metabolic acidosis associated with diarrhea or renal tubular acidosis (i.e., defect in renal $\mathrm{H}^{+}$secretion) has a normal anion gap. In contrast, if the anion of the nonvolatile acid is not $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$(e.g., lactate, $\beta$-hydroxybutyrate), the anion gap will increase (i.e., the decrease in $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$is not matched by an increase in $\left[\mathrm{Cl}^{-}\right]$but rather by an increase in the concentration of the unmeasured anion). The anion gap is increased in metabolic acidosis-associated ketoacidosis (e.g., diabetes mellitus) with renal failure, lactic acidosis, or ingestion of toxins or certain drugs (e.g., large quantities of aspirin). Thus, calculation of the anion gap is a useful way of identifying the etiology of metabolic acidosis in the clinical setting.

Albumin is a negatively charged macromolecule, and it makes a considerable contribution to "unmeasured anions." As a result, the anion gap must be adjusted in patients who have an abnormal serum [albumin]. For each $1 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{dL}$ change in serum [albumin], the anion gap needs to be adjusted in the same direction by $2.5 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$.

## Metabolic Alkalosis

Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by an increased ECF $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$and pH . It can occur via the addition of nonvolatile base to the body (e.g., ingestion of antacids), as a result of volume contraction (e.g., hemorrhage), or more commonly from loss of nonvolatile acid (e.g., loss of gastric HCl because of prolonged vomiting). Buffering occurs predominantly in the ECF and to a lesser degree in the ICF. The increase in the pH inhibits the respiratory centers, which reduces the ventilatory rate, thus the $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ is elevated (respiratory compensation).

The renal compensatory response to metabolic alkalosis is to increase excretion of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$by reducing its reabsorption along the nephron. Normally this occurs quite rapidly (minutes to hours) and effectively. Enhanced renal excretion of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$eventually returns the pH and $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$to
normal, provided the underlying cause of the initial acidbase disturbance is corrected. When the pH is corrected, the ventilatory rate also returns to normal.

## Respiratory Acidosis

Respiratory acidosis is characterized by an elevated $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ and reduced ECF pH . It results from decreased gas exchange across the alveoli as a result of either inadequate ventilation (e.g., drug-induced depression of the respiratory centers) or impaired gas diffusion (e.g., pulmonary edema, such as occurs in cardiovascular and lung disease). In contrast to the metabolic disorders, buffering during respiratory acidosis occurs almost entirely in the ICF compartment. The increase in $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ and the decrease in pH stimulate both $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$reabsorption by the nephron and titratable acid and $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$excretion (renal compensation). Together these responses increase RNAE and generate new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$. The renal compensatory response takes several days to occur. Consequently, respiratory acid-base disorders are commonly divided into acute and chronic phases. In the acute phase the time for the renal compensatory response is not sufficient, and the body relies on ICF buffering to minimize the change in pH . In the chronic phase, renal compensation occurs. Correction of the underlying disorder returns the $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ to normal and RNAE decreases to its initial level.

## Respiratory Alkalosis

Respiratory alkalosis is characterized by a reduced $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ and an increased ECF pH . It results from increased gas exchange in the lungs, usually caused by increased ventilation from stimulation of the respiratory centers (e.g., via drugs or disorders of the central nervous system). Hyperventilation also occurs at high altitude and as a result of anxiety, pain, or fear. Buffering is primarily in the ICF compartment. As with respiratory acidosis, respiratory alkalosis has both acute and chronic phases reflecting the time required for renal compensation to occur. The acute phase of respiratory alkalosis reflects intracellular buffering, whereas the chronic phase reflects renal compensation. With renal compensation, the elevated pH and reduced $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ inhibit $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$ reabsorption by the nephron and reduce titratable acid and $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$excretion. As a result of these effects, RNAE is reduced. Correction of the underlying disorder returns the $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ to normal, and renal excretion of acid then increases to its initial level.

## Analysis of Acid-Base Disorders

Analysis of an acid-base disorder is directed at identifying the underlying cause so appropriate therapy can be initiated. The patient's medical history and associated physical findings often provide valuable clues about the nature and origin of an acid-base disorder. In addition, analysis of an arterial blood sample is frequently required. Such an analysis is straightforward if approached systematically. For example, consider the following data: The acid-base disorder

represented by these values or any other set of values can be determined using the following three-step approach:

1. Examination of the pH . When pH is considered first, the underlying disorder can be classified as either an acidosis or an alkalosis. The defense mechanisms of the body cannot correct an acid-base disorder by themselves. Thus, even if the defense mechanisms are completely operative, the change in pH indicates the acid-base disorder. In the example provided, the pH of 7.35 indicates acidosis.
2. Determination of metabolic versus respiratory disorder. Simple acid-base disorders are either metabolic or respiratory. To determine which disorder is present, the clinician must next examine the ECF $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$and $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$. As previously discussed, acidosis could be the result of a decrease in $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$(metabolic) or an increase in $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ (respiratory). Alternatively, alkalosis could be the result of an increase in ECF $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$(metabolic) or a decrease in $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ (respiratory). For the example provided, the ECF $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$is reduced from normal (normal $=24 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$ ), as is the $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ (normal $=40 \mathrm{~mm} \mathrm{Hg}$ ). The disorder must therefore be metabolic acidosis; it cannot be a respiratory acidosis because the $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ is reduced.
3. Analysis of a compensatory response. Metabolic disorders result in compensatory changes in ventilation and thus in $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$, whereas respiratory disorders result in compensatory changes in RNAE and thus in ECF $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$(Table 37.2). In an appropriately compensated metabolic acidosis, the $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ is decreased, whereas it is elevated in compensated metabolic alkalosis. With respiratory acidosis, compensation results in an elevation of the $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$.

Conversely, ECF $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$is reduced in response to respiratory alkalosis. In this example, the $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ is reduced from normal, and the magnitude of this reduction ( 10 mm Hg decrease in $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ for an $8 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$ decrease in ECF $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$) is as expected (see Table 37.2). Therefore the acid-base disorder is a simple metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation.
A mixed acid-base disorder reflects the presence of two or more underlying causes for the acid-base disturbance. For example, consider the following data:

When the three-step approach is followed, it is evident that the disturbance is an acidosis that has both a metabolic component (ECF $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]<24 \mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$ ) and a respiratory component $\left(\mathrm{PCO}_{2}>40 \mathrm{~mm} \mathrm{Hg}\right)$. Thus this disorder is mixed. Mixed acid-base disorders can occur, for example, in an individual who has a history of a chronic pulmonary disease such as emphysema (i.e., chronic respiratory acidosis) and who develops an acute gastrointestinal illness with diarrhea. Because diarrhea fluid contains $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$, its loss from the body results in the development of metabolic acidosis.

A mixed acid-base disorder is also indicated when a patient has abnormal $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ and ECF $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$values but the pH is normal. Such a condition can develop in a patient who has ingested a large quantity of aspirin. Salicylic acid (active ingredient in aspirin) produces metabolic acidosis and at the same time stimulates the respiratory centers, causing hyperventilation and respiratory alkalosis. Thus, the patient has a reduced ECF $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$and a reduced $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$. (NOTE: The $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ is lower than would occur with normal respiratory compensation of a metabolic acidosis.)

## Key Concepts

1. The kidneys maintain acid-base balance through excretion of an amount of acid equal to the amount of nonvolatile acid produced by metabolism and the quantity ingested in the diet (termed renal net acid excretion
[RNAE]). The kidneys also prevent loss of $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$in urine by reabsorbing virtually all the $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$filtered at the glomeruli. Both reabsorption of filtered $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$and excretion of acid are accomplished by secretion of $\mathrm{H}^{+}$by

the nephrons. Acid is excreted by the kidneys in the form of titratable acid (primarily as $\mathrm{P}_{i}$ ) and $\mathrm{NH}_{4}^{+}$. Both titratable acid and $\mathrm{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$excretion result in generation of new $\mathrm{HCO}_{3}{ }^{-}$, which replenishes the $\mathrm{ECF} \mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}$lost during neutralization of nonvolatile acids.
2. The body uses three lines of defense to minimize the impact of acid-base disorders on body fluid pH : (1) ECF and ICF buffering, (2) respiratory compensation, and (3) renal compensation.
3. Metabolic acid-base disorders result from primary alterations in ECF $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$, which in turn results from addition of acid to or loss of alkali from the body. In response to metabolic acidosis, pulmonary ventilation is increased,
which decreases $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$. The pulmonary response to metabolic acid-base disorders occurs in a matter of minutes. RNAE is also increased, but this takes several days. An increase in ECF $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]$causes alkalosis. This rapidly (minutes to hours) decreases pulmonary ventilation, which elevates $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ as a compensatory response. RNAE is also decreased, but this takes several days.
4. Respiratory acid-base disorders result from primary alterations in $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$. Elevation of $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ produces acidosis, and the kidneys respond with an increase in RNAE. Conversely, a reduction of $\mathrm{PCO}_{2}$ produces alkalosis, and RNAE is reduced. The kidneys respond to respiratory acid-base disorders over several hours to days.

# 38 

## Introduction to the Endocrine System

## LEARNING OBJECTIVES

Upon completion of this chapter, the student should be able to answer the following questions:

1. Name the major endocrine glands and their hormonal product or products.
2. Map out and differentiate a simple endocrine negative feedback loop and one involving the hypothalamus, anterior pituitary and peripheral endocrine gland, and list the major endocrine glands under each type of feedback loop.
3. Define a releasing hormone and a tropic hormone.
4. Explain the chemical nature and the characteristics of protein/peptide hormones, catecholamine hormones, steroid hormones, and iodothyronines (thyroid hormones). Include such characteristics as site of regulation (synthesis or secretion), circulating form of hormone, subcellular localization of hormone receptor, and metabolic clearance.
5. Integrate the concept of peripheral conversion with the function/action of a secreted hormone.
6. Integrate the intracellular steps associated with a hormone response in a target cell.

The ability of cells to communicate with each other is an underpinning of human biology. As discussed in Chapter 3, cell-to-cell communication occurs at various levels of complexity and distance. Endocrine signaling involves (1) the regulated secretion of an extracellular signaling molecule, called a hormone, into the extracellular fluid; (2) diffusion of the hormone into the vasculature and its circulation throughout the body; and (3) diffusion of the hormone out of the vascular compartment into the extracellular space and binding to a specific receptor within cells of a target organ. Because of the spread of hormones throughout the body, one hormone often regulates the activity of several target organs. Conversely, cells frequently express receptors for multiple hormones.

The endocrine system is a collection of glands whose function is to regulate multiple organs within the body to (1) meet the growth and reproductive needs of the organism and (2) respond to fluctuations within the internal environment, including various types of stress. The endocrine system is composed of three subsets of organs:

1. Glands that are solely dedicated to an endocrine function, involving the synthesis and secretion of bioactive hormones. These include (Fig. 38.1):

Parathyroid glands
Pituitary gland
Thyroid gland
Adrenal glands
2. Gonads, which have a major endocrine function, as well as gametogenic function.
Gonads (testes or ovaries) (Table 38.1). A transitory organ, the placenta, also performs a major endocrine function.
3. Isolated endocrine cells or endocrine cell clusters within organs whose primary function is not endocrine (see Table 38.1). These include cells within the heart that produce atrial natriuretic peptide, liver cells that produce insulin-like growth factor type 1 (IGF-1), cells within the kidney that produce erythropoietin, cell clusters within the pancreas that produce insulin and glucagon, and numerous cell types within the gastrointestinal tract that produce gastrointestinal hormones. There also exist collections of cell bodies (called nuclei) within the hypothalamus that secrete peptides, called neurohormones, into capillaries associated with the pituitary gland.
A fourth subset of the endocrine system is represented by numerous cell types that express intracellular enzymes, ectoenzymes, or secreted enzymes that modify inactive precursors or less active hormones into highly active hormones (see Table 38.1). An example is the generation of angiotensin II from the inactive polypeptide angiotensinogen by two subsequent proteolytic cleavages (see Chapter 43). Another example is activation of vitamin D by two subsequent hydroxylation reactions in the liver and kidneys to produce the highly bioactive hormone 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (vitamin D).

## Configuration of Feedback Loops Within the Endocrine System

The predominant mode of a closed feedback loop among endocrine glands is negative feedback. In a negative feedback loop, a hormone acts on one or more target organs to induce a change (either a decrease or an increase) in circulating levels of a specific component, and the change in this component then inhibits secretion of the hormone. Negative feedback loops confer stability by keeping a physiological parameter (e.g., blood glucose level) within a normal range. There are also a few examples of positive feedback

![be60294790948](be60294790948.jpg)

- Fig. 38.1 Glands of the endocrine system.
in endocrine regulation. A closed positive feedback loop, in which a hormone increases levels of a specific component and this component stimulates further secretion of the hormone, confers instability. Under the control of positive feedback loops, something has got to give; for example, positive feedback loops control processes that lead to rupture of a follicle through the ovarian wall or expulsion of a fetus from the uterus.

There are two basic configurations of negative feedback loops within the endocrine system: a physiological response-driven feedback loop (referred to simply as a response-driven feedback loop) and an endocrine axis-driven feedback loop (Fig. 38.2). The response-driven feedback loop is observed in endocrine glands that control blood glucose levels (pancreatic islet cells), blood $\mathrm{Ca}^{++}$and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}$ levels (parathyroid glands, kidneys), blood osmolarity and volume (hypothalamus/posterior pituitary gland), and blood $\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{K}^{+}$, and $\mathrm{H}^{+}$levels (zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex and atrial cells). In the response-driven configuration, secretion of a hormone is stimulated or inhibited by a change in the level of a specific extracellular parameter (e.g., an increase in blood glucose level stimulates insulin secretion). Alterations in hormone levels lead to changes in the physiological characteristics of target organs (e.g., decreased hepatic gluconeogenesis, increased uptake of glucose by muscle) that directly regulate the parameter (in this case, blood glucose level) in question. The change in the parameter (decreased blood glucose level) then inhibits further secretion of the hormone (i.e., insulin secretion drops as blood glucose level falls). This type of feedback also involves the response of endocrine cells to changes in the contents of lumens of other organ systems, especially the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract.

Much of the endocrine system is organized into endocrine axes; each axis consists of the hypothalamus, the pituitary gland, and the peripheral endocrine glands (see Fig. 38.2). Thus, the endocrine axis-driven feedback loop
involves a three-tiered configuration. The first tier is represented by hypothalamic neuroendocrine neurons that secrete releasing hormones. Releasing hormones stimulate (or, in a few cases, inhibit) the production and secretion of tropic hormones from the pituitary gland (second tier). Tropic hormones stimulate the production and secretion of hormones from peripheral endocrine glands (third tier). The peripherally produced hormones-namely, thyroid hormone, cortisol, sex steroids, and IGF-1âtypically have pleiotropic actions (e.g., multiple phenotypic effects) on numerous cell types. Additionally, these peripherally produced hormones exert the primary feedback loop that inhibits the release of pituitary tropic hormones and hypothalamic releasing hormones. In contrast to response-driven feedback, the physiological responses to the peripherally produced hormone play only a minor role in regulation of feedback within endocrine axis-driven feedback loops. From a clinical perspective, endocrine diseases are described as primary, secondary, or tertiary diseases (e.g., secondary hyperthyroidism, tertiary hypogonadism). Primary disease is a lesion in the peripheral endocrine gland; secondary disease is a lesion in the anterior pituitary gland; and tertiary disease is a lesion in the hypothalamus.

An important aspect of the endocrine axes is the ability of descending and ascending neuronal signals to modulate release of the hypothalamic releasing hormones and thereby control the activity of the axis. A major neuronal input to releasing hormone-secreting neurons comes from another region of the hypothalamus called the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN). SCN neurons impose a daily rhythm, called a circadian rhythm, on the secretion of hypothalamic releasing hormones and the endocrine axes that they control (Fig. 38.3). SCN neurons represent an intrinsic circadian clock, as evidenced by the fact that they demonstrate a spontaneous peak of electrical activity at the same time every 24 to 25 hours. The 24 - to 25 -hour cycle can be "entrained" by the normal environmental light-dark cycle

The pineal gland forms a neuroendocrine link between the SCN and various physiological processes that require circadian control. This tiny gland, close to the hypothalamus, synthesizes the hormone melatonin from the neurotransmitter serotonin. The rate-limiting enzyme for melatonin synthesis is N -acetyltransferase. The amount and activity of this enzyme in the pineal gland vary markedly in a cyclic manner, which accounts for the cycling of melatonin secretion and its plasma levels. Synthesis of melatonin is inhibited by light and markedly stimulated by darkness (Fig. 38.4). Thus, melatonin may transmit the information that nighttime has arrived, and body functions are regulated accordingly. Melatonin feedback to the SCN at dawn or dusk may also help evoke day-night entrainment of the SCN 24- to 25 -hour clock. Melatonin has numerous other actions, including induction of sleep.

Another important input to hypothalamic neurons and the pituitary gland is stress, either as systemic stress (e.g., hemorrhage, inflammation) or as processive stress (e.g., fear, anxiety). Major medical or surgical stress overrides the circadian clock and causes a pattern of persistent and exaggerated hormone release and metabolism that mobilizes endogenous fuels, such as glucose and free fatty acids, and augments their delivery to critical organs. Growth and reproductive processes, in contrast, are suppressed. In addition, cytokines released during inflammatory or immune responses, or
both, directly regulate the release of hypothalamic releasing hormones and pituitary hormones.

## Chemical Nature of Hormones

Hormones are classified biochemically as proteins/peptides, catecholamines, steroid hormones, or iodothyronines. The chemical nature of a hormone determines (1) how it is synthesized, stored, and released; (2) how it is transported in blood; (3) its biological half-life and mode of clearance; and (4) its cellular mechanism of action.

## Proteins/Peptides

Protein and peptide hormones can be grouped into structurally related molecules that are encoded by gene families. Protein/peptide hormones obtain their specificity from their primary amino acid sequence and from post-translational modifications, especially glycosylation.

Because protein/peptide hormones are destined for secretion outside the cell, their synthesis and processing are differently from those of proteins destined to remain within the cell or to be continuously added to the membrane (Fig. 38.5). These hormones are synthesized on the polyribosome as larger preprohormones or prehormones. The nascent peptides have at their N -terminus a group of 15 to 30 amino acids called the signal peptide. The signal peptide interacts with a ribonucleoprotein particle, which ultimately directs the growing peptide chain through a pore in the membrane of the endoplasmic

![be60494790948](be60494790948.jpg)

Removal of the signal peptide by a signal peptidase generates a hormone or prohormone, which is then transported from the cisternae of the endoplasmic reticulum to the Golgi apparatus, where it is packaged into a membrane-bound secretory vesicle that is subsequently released into the cytoplasm.
